PAN Sorasak, Minister of Commerce (MOC), Cambodia, and Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), held an online courtesy call this morning to discuss the 19 Priority Economic Deliverables (PEDs) under the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) Pillar, as endorsed at the 28<sup>th</sup>&nbsp;ASEAN Economic Ministers&rsquo; (AEM) Retreat on 16 March.</p><p>As the Chair of ASEAN in 2022, Cambodia is committed to lead ASEAN under the theme of &lsquo;ASEAN A.C.T: Addressing Challenges Together&rsquo;, to foster harmony and prosperity in the region. In the discussion, led by H.E. PAN Sorasak, the Minister expressed his utmost appreciation for ERIA&rsquo;s continuous technical, intellectual and financial support, which is also reflected in ERIA&rsquo;s longstanding Capacity Building Programme for Cambodian officials.</p><p>Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura affirmed ERIA&rsquo;s commitment to support Cambodia&rsquo;s Chairmanship, as mandated of ERIA. He went on to note ERIA&rsquo;s support for Cambodia&rsquo;s Chairmanship in 2012, and our desire to contribute to the success of this year&rsquo;s Chairmanship.</p><p>Mr ENG Sothyvon, Director, Department of Asia-Pacific, SEOM Lead for Cambodia in 2022, then presented the details of the 19 PEDs, including the objectives and expected outcomes of the PEDs clustered under four &lsquo;Key Strategic Thrusts&rsquo;. In response to the presentation, Mr Koji Hachiyama, ERIA&rsquo;s Chief Operating Officer, commented on how ERIA could contribute to the various PEDs. Prof Fukunari Kimura, ERIA&rsquo;s Chief Economist, also emphasized the importance of these deliverables to support economic integration being challenged by dynamic geopolitical issues. Dr Keita Oikawa, ERIA Economist, then presented the Comprehensive Asia Development Plan 3.0 (CADP 3.0) that covers four pillars including integration, innovation, inclusiveness, and sustainability toward regional economic development, noting how it contributes to the PEDs.</p><p>In his closing remarks, H.E. PAN Sorasak welcomed the partnership between Cambodia and ERIA. Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura also reaffirmed ERIA&rsquo;s full commitment to support the 19 PEDs under the AEC pillar led by the Cambodian chairmanship.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:79:"/uploads/articles/20220323/2022-mar-courtesy-call-with-he-pan-sorasak-5-800.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:5039:"ERIA President Discusses ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) Pillar with the Minister of Commerce of Cambodia ERIA President Discusses ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) Pillar with the Minister of Commerce of Cambodia Jakarta, 23 March 2022, H.E. PAN Sorasak, Minister of Commerce (MOC), Cambodia, and Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), held an online courtesy call this morning to discuss the 19 Priority Economic Deliverables (PEDs) under the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) Pillar, as endorsed at the 28th&nbsp;ASEAN Economic Ministers&rsquo; (AEM) Retreat on 16 March.
As the Chair of ASEAN in 2022, Cambodia is committed to lead ASEAN under the theme of &lsquo;ASEAN A.C.T: Addressing Challenges Together&rsquo;, to foster harmony and prosperity in the region. In the discussion, led by H.E. PAN Sorasak, the Minister expressed his utmost appreciation for ERIA&rsquo;s continuous technical, intellectual and financial support, which is also reflected in ERIA&rsquo;s longstanding Capacity Building Programme for Cambodian officials.
Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura affirmed ERIA&rsquo;s commitment to support Cambodia&rsquo;s Chairmanship, as mandated of ERIA. He went on to note ERIA&rsquo;s support for Cambodia&rsquo;s Chairmanship in 2012, and our desire to contribute to the success of this year&rsquo;s Chairmanship.
Mr ENG Sothyvon, Director, Department of Asia-Pacific, SEOM Lead for Cambodia in 2022, then presented the details of the 19 PEDs, including the objectives and expected outcomes of the PEDs clustered under four &lsquo;Key Strategic Thrusts&rsquo;. In response to the presentation, Mr Koji Hachiyama, ERIA&rsquo;s Chief Operating Officer, commented on how ERIA could contribute to the various PEDs. Prof Fukunari Kimura, ERIA&rsquo;s Chief Economist, also emphasized the importance of these deliverables to support economic integration being challenged by dynamic geopolitical issues. Dr Keita Oikawa, ERIA Economist, then presented the Comprehensive Asia Development Plan 3.0 (CADP 3.0) that covers four pillars including integration, innovation, inclusiveness, and sustainability toward regional economic development, noting how it contributes to the PEDs.
In his closing remarks, H.E. PAN Sorasak welcomed the partnership between Cambodia and ERIA. Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura also reaffirmed ERIA&rsquo;s full commitment to support the 19 PEDs under the AEC pillar led by the Cambodian chairmanship.             2022-03-23 23 March 2022 2202 hcraM 32 32-30-2202             .pihsnamriahc naidobmaC eht yb del rallip CEA eht rednu sDEP 91 eht troppus ot tnemtimmoc lluf s;ouqsr&AIRE demriffaer osla arumihsiN ihsotediH forP .AIRE dna aidobmaC neewteb pihsrentrap eht democlew kasaroS NAP .E.H ,skramer gnisolc sih nI

cimonocE NAESA sessucsiD tnediserP AIRE";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-05-25 13:58:37";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-05-25 13:58:37";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";N;s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:79;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6767";s:12:"article_type";s:8:"articles";s:3:"uri";s:56:"eria-cadp-research-team-conducts-site-visits-in-cambodia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:56:"ERIA CADP Research Team Conducts Site Visits in Cambodia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2016-12-06";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2016";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"12";s:7:"content";s:2780:"<p><strong>Poipet, 6 December 2016:</strong> From 30 October to 2 November 2016, a research team from the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) on the Comprehensive Asia Development Plan (CADP) travelled from Pleiku in Viet Nam to Poipet in Cambodia by car.</p><p>The purpose of the road trip was to conduct a site visit to several infrastructure projects that are listed in&nbsp;<a href="/publications/research_project_reports/the-comprehensive-asia-development-plan.html">CADP 1.0</a>,&nbsp;<a href="/publications/key_reports/FY2014/No.04.html">CADP 2.0</a>, as well as other projects related to the ASEAN Connectivity and Southern Economic Corridor of the Greater Mekong Subregion.</p><p>Along the Cambodian National Road No.9 in Ratanakiri province, which was&nbsp;<a href="/publications/research_project_reports/images/pdf/y2009/no7-1/Appendix1.pdf">listed in CADP 1.0</a>, there were many big plantations that produce various crops such as cashew nuts, pepper, and cassava. The plantations and processing factories along the National Road will benefit from improved electricity supply and accessible road networks, which will help promote the development of agroprocessing industries in this area to boost exports of value-added products from Cambodia.</p><p>The research team noted significant progress in the restoration of the Royal Railway of Cambodia&#039;s North Line (known as the Missing Link). The Friendship Railway Bridge that connects the Cambodian and Thai railways in Poipet was completed in September 2016, while the reconstruction of the railroad between Sisophon and Poipet (<a href="/RPR_FY2014_No.4_Appendix_1.pdf">listed in CADP 2.0</a>) is expected to be finished in 2017.</p><p>In addition to roads and railways, CADP 2.0 also listed the development of several Special Economic Zones (SEZ) in Poipet among its projects in order to attract foreign investors, especially those that implement &#039;Thailand-Plus-One&#039; strategy and will broaden their supply chain network from Thailand to Cambodia. One SEZ, the Techno Park Poipet managed by Toyota Tsusho Corporation, has completed the construction phase and started its sales operation on 1 September 2016.</p><p>As part of efforts to address other issues that have been plaguing investors such as inadequate electricity supply, scarcity of skilled labour, and high logistics cost, last year the Royal Government of Cambodia launched Cambodia Industrial Development Policy 2015-2025 (IDP). The ERIA CADP research team noted the steady progress of infrastructure developments in Cambodia in line with the direction proposed in IDP and CADP2.0. The team would continue its follow-up study of CADP2.0 to ensure the continuous implementation of CADP 2.0 projects in this region.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:104:"/uploads/articles/20161206/2016_dec_eria-cadp-research-team-conducts-site-visits-in-cambodia_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:5155:"ERIA CADP Research Team Conducts Site Visits in Cambodia ERIA CADP Research Team Conducts Site Visits in Cambodia Poipet, 6 December 2016: From 30 October to 2 November 2016, a research team from the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) on the Comprehensive Asia Development Plan (CADP) travelled from Pleiku in Viet Nam to Poipet in Cambodia by car.
The purpose of the road trip was to conduct a site visit to several infrastructure projects that are listed in&nbsp;CADP 1.0,&nbsp;CADP 2.0, as well as other projects related to the ASEAN Connectivity and Southern Economic Corridor of the Greater Mekong Subregion.
Along the Cambodian National Road No.9 in Ratanakiri province, which was&nbsp;listed in CADP 1.0, there were many big plantations that produce various crops such as cashew nuts, pepper, and cassava. The plantations and processing factories along the National Road will benefit from improved electricity supply and accessible road networks, which will help promote the development of agroprocessing industries in this area to boost exports of value-added products from Cambodia.
The research team noted significant progress in the restoration of the Royal Railway of Cambodia's North Line (known as the Missing Link). The Friendship Railway Bridge that connects the Cambodian and Thai railways in Poipet was completed in September 2016, while the reconstruction of the railroad between Sisophon and Poipet (listed in CADP 2.0) is expected to be finished in 2017.
In addition to roads and railways, CADP 2.0 also listed the development of several Special Economic Zones (SEZ) in Poipet among its projects in order to attract foreign investors, especially those that implement 'Thailand-Plus-One' strategy and will broaden their supply chain network from Thailand to Cambodia. One SEZ, the Techno Park Poipet managed by Toyota Tsusho Corporation, has completed the construction phase and started its sales operation on 1 September 2016.
As part of efforts to address other issues that have been plaguing investors such as inadequate electricity supply, scarcity of skilled labour, and high logistics cost, last year the Royal Government of Cambodia launched Cambodia Industrial Development Policy 2015-2025 (IDP). The ERIA CADP research team noted the steady progress of infrastructure developments in Cambodia in line with the direction proposed in IDP and CADP2.0. The team would continue its follow-up study of CADP2.0 to ensure the continuous implementation of CADP 2.0 projects in this region.             2016-12-06 6 December 2016 6102 rebmeceD 6 60-21-6102             .noiger siht ni stcejorp 0.2 PDAC fo noitatnemelpmi suounitnoc eht erusne ot 0.2PDAC fo yduts pu-wollof sti eunitnoc dluow maet ehT .0.2PDAC dna PDI ni desoporp noitcerid eht htiw enil ni aidobmaC ni stnempoleved erutcurtsarfni fo ssergorp ydaets eht deton maet hcraeser PDAC AIRE ehT .)PDI( 5202-5102 yciloP tnempoleveD lairtsudnI aidobmaC dehcnual aidobmaC fo tnemnrevoG layoR eht raey tsal ,tsoc scitsigol hgih dna ,ruobal delliks fo yticracs ,ylppus yticirtcele etauqedani sa hcus srotsevni gniugalp neeb evah taht seussi rehto sserdda ot stroffe fo trap sA

The participants also discussed issues surrounding&nbsp;<a title="CADP infrastructure projects map" href="http://map.eria.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">infrastructure projects in every Southeast Asian country</a>. The input and ideas provided during the event facilitates the completion of the CADP 3.0.</p><p>Since the initial launch of&nbsp;<a href="/publications/research_project_reports/the-comprehensive-asia-development-plan.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">CADP 1.0</a>&nbsp;in 2010, it has become a highly-important and oft-referred document by ASEAN government leaders and industry experts. CADP 1.0 listed out the long-term strategy of improving ASEAN&rsquo;s participation in international production networks which has evolved over the years. Released in 2015,&nbsp;<a href="/publications/key_reports/FY2014/No.04.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">CADP 2.0</a>&nbsp;identified 761 infrastructure projects believed to contribute to connectivity and innovation progress. CADP 3.0 is planned to be published in 2020 with the objective of achieving a higher level of &lsquo;unbundling&rsquo;, a term coined by&nbsp;<a href="/news-and-views/eria-and-csis-hold-private-discussion-with-prof-richard-baldwin/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Prof Richard Baldwin</a>. ERIA&rsquo;s Chief Economist, Prof Fukunari Kimura, issued a&nbsp;<a href="/uploads/media/ERIA-DP-2017-14.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">discussion paper</a>&nbsp;on Baldwin&rsquo;s concept in 2017.</p><p>Although ASEAN Member States are at different phases of their infrastructure development, workshop participants remain confident in enhancing their regional connectivity. The aim of such effort is to further push for industrialisation and economic growth in ASEAN. As of 2018, 56% of the infrastructure projects listed in CADP 2.0 have either been completed or nearing completion. This infrastructure advancement made by ASEAN between 2015-2018 indicated the region&rsquo;s affirmation in creating a strong industry and achieving robust connectivity. Following on from the workshop, ERIA will soon begin accepting and selecting infrastructure project proposals by ASEAN Member-States due to be included in CADP 3.0.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:64:"/uploads/articles/20190426/2019_april_cadp-3_1_800x450-5-800.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4725:"ERIA Hosts Workshop on CADP 3.0 Infrastructure Projects ERIA Hosts Workshop on CADP 3.0 Infrastructure Projects Jakarta, 26 April 2019:&nbsp;The Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) conducted a workshop on Southeast Asia&rsquo;s infrastructure projects and its progress, as part of the upcoming&nbsp;Comprehensive Asia Development Plan&nbsp;(CADP) 3.0 project.
Prominent experts from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations&rsquo; (ASEAN) public sector as well as leading think tanks attended the workshop, which was led by ERIA&rsquo;s Senior Policy Advisor, Mr Takafumi Fujisawa and ERIA&rsquo;s Economist, Dr Masahito Ambashi. The participants also discussed issues surrounding&nbsp;infrastructure projects in every Southeast Asian country. The input and ideas provided during the event facilitates the completion of the CADP 3.0.
Since the initial launch of&nbsp;CADP 1.0&nbsp;in 2010, it has become a highly-important and oft-referred document by ASEAN government leaders and industry experts. CADP 1.0 listed out the long-term strategy of improving ASEAN&rsquo;s participation in international production networks which has evolved over the years. Released in 2015,&nbsp;CADP 2.0&nbsp;identified 761 infrastructure projects believed to contribute to connectivity and innovation progress. CADP 3.0 is planned to be published in 2020 with the objective of achieving a higher level of &lsquo;unbundling&rsquo;, a term coined by&nbsp;Prof Richard Baldwin. ERIA&rsquo;s Chief Economist, Prof Fukunari Kimura, issued a&nbsp;discussion paper&nbsp;on Baldwin&rsquo;s concept in 2017.
Although ASEAN Member States are at different phases of their infrastructure development, workshop participants remain confident in enhancing their regional connectivity. The aim of such effort is to further push for industrialisation and economic growth in ASEAN. As of 2018, 56% of the infrastructure projects listed in CADP 2.0 have either been completed or nearing completion. This infrastructure advancement made by ASEAN between 2015-2018 indicated the region&rsquo;s affirmation in creating a strong industry and achieving robust connectivity. Following on from the workshop, ERIA will soon begin accepting and selecting infrastructure project proposals by ASEAN Member-States due to be included in CADP 3.0.             2019-04-26 26 April 2019 9102 lirpA 62 62-40-9102             .0.3 PDAC ni dedulcni eb ot eud setatS-rebmeM NAESA yb slasoporp tcejorp erutcurtsarfni gnitceles dna gnitpecca nigeb noos lliw AIRE ,pohskrow eht morf no gniwolloF .ytivitcennoc tsubor gniveihca dna yrtsudni gnorts a gnitaerc ni noitamriffa s;ouqsr&noiger eht detacidni 8102-5102 neewteb NAESA yb edam tnemecnavda erutcurtsarfni sihT .noitelpmoc gniraen ro detelpmoc neeb rehtie evah 0.2 PDAC ni detsil stcejorp erutcurtsarfni eht fo %65 ,8102 fo sA .NAESA ni htworg cimonoce dna noitasilairtsudni rof hsup rehtruf ot si troffe hcus fo mia ehT .ytivitcennoc lanoiger rieht gnicnahne ni tnedifnoc niamer stnapicitrap pohskrow ,tnempoleved erutcurtsarfni rieht fo sesahp tnereffid ta era setatS rebmeM NAESA hguohtlA

It will play a key role in the world&rsquo;s transition to net-zero emissions of greenhouse gasses by 2050 and is one of the six priority agendas in the financial track of Indonesia&rsquo;s Group of Twenty (G20) 2022 presidency.</p><p>Such were some of the views presented by Dr Lili Yan Ing, ERIA&rsquo;s lead advisor on Southeast Asia, during the . She said the current state of world development has two long-standing issues: inequality and climate change. She emphasised that global economic recovery should not come at the expense of poverty alleviation and the green economy. Both can be pursued at the same time, she added, by wider use of sustainable finance as nations and businesses develop.</p><p>As a recommendation to G20, Dr Lili suggested the enhancement of the role of multilateral development banks and the further development of carbon markets. With the current contraction of the world&rsquo;s economy, Dr Lili said that fiscal policy will play an important role in meeting Indonesia&rsquo;s sustainable development goals. Quoting US economist Joseph Stiglitz, Dr Lili said that development is not just about transforming economies but also transforming lives.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:108:"/uploads/articles/20220518/2022_may_sustainable-finance-to-tackle-inequality-and-climate-change_800x450.jpeg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3227:"Sustainable Finance Sought to Tackle Inequality, Climate Change Sustainable Finance Sought to Tackle Inequality, Climate Change Surakarta, 18 May 2022:&nbsp;Sustainable finance refers to any form of financing that incorporates environmental, social, and governance aspects into business and investment decisions. &nbsp;Sustainable finance aims towards greater benefits for clients and for society as a whole. It will play a key role in the world&rsquo;s transition to net-zero emissions of greenhouse gasses by 2050 and is one of the six priority agendas in the financial track of Indonesia&rsquo;s Group of Twenty (G20) 2022 presidency.
Such were some of the views presented by Dr Lili Yan Ing, ERIA&rsquo;s lead advisor on Southeast Asia, during the . She said the current state of world development has two long-standing issues: inequality and climate change. She emphasised that global economic recovery should not come at the expense of poverty alleviation and the green economy. Both can be pursued at the same time, she added, by wider use of sustainable finance as nations and businesses develop.
As a recommendation to G20, Dr Lili suggested the enhancement of the role of multilateral development banks and the further development of carbon markets. With the current contraction of the world&rsquo;s economy, Dr Lili said that fiscal policy will play an important role in meeting Indonesia&rsquo;s sustainable development goals. Quoting US economist Joseph Stiglitz, Dr Lili said that development is not just about transforming economies but also transforming lives.             2022-05-18 18 May 2022 2202 yaM 81 81-50-2202             .sevil gnimrofsnart osla tub seimonoce gnimrofsnart tuoba tsuj ton si tnempoleved taht dias iliL rD ,ztilgitS hpesoJ tsimonoce SU gnitouQ .slaog tnempoleved elbaniatsus s;ouqsr&aisenodnI gniteem ni elor tnatropmi na yalp lliw ycilop lacsif taht dias iliL rD ,ymonoce s;ouqsr&dlrow eht fo noitcartnoc tnerruc eht htiW .stekram nobrac fo tnempoleved rehtruf eht dna sknab tnempoleved laretalitlum fo elor eht fo tnemecnahne eht detseggus iliL rD ,02G ot noitadnemmocer a sA

The High-level Policy Dialogue on Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TII-WG) is organised by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the International Energy Agency (IEA) and will be a side event of the Group of Twenty (G20) meeting&nbsp;that will be held virtually in July 2022.</p><p>At the April meeting, ERIA&rsquo;s Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia Dr Lili Yan Ing, ERIA&rsquo;s Senior Economist Dr Fauziah Zen, and ERIA&rsquo;s Senior Economist Dr Doan Thi Thanh Ha were joined by the G20 Presidency on Trade, Investment, and Industry team that included Director of APEC Negotiations and International Organization of Ministry of Trade Mr Reza Pahlevi, Deputy Minister of Investment Dr Riyatno, Special Advisor to the Minister of Investment Dr Indra Darmawan, Special Staff to the Minister of Investment on National Entrepreneurship Development Mr M. Pradana Indraputra, Deputy Director of Intra-regional Cooperation of the Ministry of Investment Mr Fajar Usman, and Director of International Industrial Access of the Ministry of Industry Mr Yan Sibarang Tandiele.</p><p>Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 expert team, led by Dr Ing and Prof Rodrik, will discuss economic recovery, digital transformation, and sustainable development at the dialogue. At the pre-dialogue meeting, Dr Ing reaffirmed ERIA&rsquo;s commitment to support the dialogue. Also discussed was the second G20 TII-WG meeting to be held on 4&ndash;7 July 2022, which will tackle three priority issues: World Trade Organization reform, response to the COVID-19 pandemic and global health architecture, and sustainable investment for economic recovery.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:131:"/uploads/articles/20220427/2022_april_experts-meet-ahead-of-g20-high-level-policy-dialogue-on-trade-investment-industry_800x450.png";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3971:"Experts Meet Ahead of G20 High-Level Policy Dialogue on Trade, Investment, Industry Experts Meet Ahead of G20 High-Level Policy Dialogue on Trade, Investment, Industry Jakarta, 27 April 2022:&nbsp;Several economic experts met in April to prepare for a high-level policy dialogue to be held in mid-July 2022. The High-level Policy Dialogue on Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TII-WG) is organised by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the International Energy Agency (IEA) and will be a side event of the Group of Twenty (G20) meeting&nbsp;that will be held virtually in July 2022.
At the April meeting, ERIA&rsquo;s Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia Dr Lili Yan Ing, ERIA&rsquo;s Senior Economist Dr Fauziah Zen, and ERIA&rsquo;s Senior Economist Dr Doan Thi Thanh Ha were joined by the G20 Presidency on Trade, Investment, and Industry team that included Director of APEC Negotiations and International Organization of Ministry of Trade Mr Reza Pahlevi, Deputy Minister of Investment Dr Riyatno, Special Advisor to the Minister of Investment Dr Indra Darmawan, Special Staff to the Minister of Investment on National Entrepreneurship Development Mr M. Pradana Indraputra, Deputy Director of Intra-regional Cooperation of the Ministry of Investment Mr Fajar Usman, and Director of International Industrial Access of the Ministry of Industry Mr Yan Sibarang Tandiele.
Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 expert team, led by Dr Ing and Prof Rodrik, will discuss economic recovery, digital transformation, and sustainable development at the dialogue. At the pre-dialogue meeting, Dr Ing reaffirmed ERIA&rsquo;s commitment to support the dialogue. Also discussed was the second G20 TII-WG meeting to be held on 4&ndash;7 July 2022, which will tackle three priority issues: World Trade Organization reform, response to the COVID-19 pandemic and global health architecture, and sustainable investment for economic recovery.             2022-04-27 27 April 2022 2202 lirpA 72 72-40-2202             .yrevocer cimonoce rof tnemtsevni elbaniatsus dna ,erutcetihcra htlaeh labolg dna cimednap 91-DIVOC eht ot esnopser ,mrofer noitazinagrO edarT dlroW :seussi ytiroirp eerht elkcat lliw hcihw ,2202 yluJ 7;hsadn&4 no dleh eb ot gniteem GW-IIT 02G dnoces eht saw dessucsid oslA .eugolaid eht troppus ot tnemtimmoc s;ouqsr&AIRE demriffaer gnI rD ,gniteem eugolaid-erp eht tA .eugolaid eht ta tnempoleved elbaniatsus dna ,noitamrofsnart latigid ,yrevocer cimonoce ssucsid lliw ,kirdoR forP dna gnI rD yb del ,maet trepxe 02G s;ouqsr&aisenodnI

leveL-hgiH 02G fo daehA teeM strepxE";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-05-09 10:46:46";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-05-09 10:46:46";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";N;s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:83;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6728";s:12:"article_type";s:8:"articles";s:3:"uri";s:108:"transposing-lao-pdrs-tariff-reduction-schedule-from-asean-harmonised-tariff-nomenclature-ahtn-2017-into-2022";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:118:"Transposing Lao PDRâ€™s Tariff Reduction Schedule from ASEAN Harmonised Tariff Nomenclature (AHTN) 2017 into 2022";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-22";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:2465:"<p><strong>Jakarta, 22 April 2022</strong>: ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme and the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, Lao PDR, co-hosted a technical training workshop on transposing Lao PDR&rsquo;s tariff reduction schedule (TRS) from ASEAN Harmonised Tariff Nomenclature (AHTN) and Harmonised System (HS) 2017 into 2022.</p><p>The ASEAN Harmonized Tariff Nomenclature (AHTN), important for simplifying intra-ASEAN trade through the establishment of uniform tariff nomenclature, is structured around the World Customs Organisation&rsquo;s HS tariffs. These need periodic updating due to changes in tariff lines. Thus, for example, since the AHTN 2017, there has been a 5.27% increase in tariff lines, taking the total to 11,414 in the AHTN 2022. This increase in tariff lines results in the need to process the TRS transposition from AHTN 2017 into the AHTN 2022.</p><p>The four-day technical training focused on the process of TRS transposition and developing recommendations about which tariffs should be used in the case of merging tariff lines under different ASEAN free trade agreements (FTAs). The training was a follow-up to one focusing on the transposition of tariff commitments from AHTN&nbsp;2012 into 2017 held in 2021. Mr Ahmad Syaukat Romawi, an expert on this topic and former ASEAN Secretariat Official, led and facilitated this technical training workshop. Mr Somphone Phady, Acting Director of the Trade in Goods Division Department led the discussions with participating officials from the Lao PDR&rsquo;s Customs Department.</p><p>Following opening comments by Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA Director of Capacity Building, in which he highlighted ERIA&rsquo;s commitment to supporting ASEAN regional trade facilitation, the training began with an overview of AHTN 2022 and the technical method employed to modify HS Correlation Table 2017-2022 in relation to the ASEAN Trade in Goods Agreement (ATIGA) and ASEAN Australia New Zealand Free Trade Agreement (AANZFTA). Day two focused on the transposition of Lao PDR&rsquo;s Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) TRS from AHTN 2012 into AHTN 2017, with day three focusing on the ASEAN with China, Japan, Korea, and India Free Trade Agreements. The final day focused on the ASEAN agreement with Hong Kong as well as RCEP Product Specific Rules (PSR) from HS 2017 into HS 2022. &nbsp;</p><p>ERIA&rsquo;s ongoing Capacity Building Programme is supported by the Australian Government.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:157:"/uploads/articles/20220422/2022_april_transposing-lao-pdr-tariff-reduction-schedule-from-asean-harmonised-tariff-nomenclature-ahtn-2017-into-2022_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:19:"ASEAN,Trade,Lao PDR";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:5431:"Transposing Lao PDRâ€™s Tariff Reduction Schedule from ASEAN Harmonised Tariff Nomenclature (AHTN) 2017 into 2022 Transposing Lao PDRâ€™s Tariff Reduction Schedule from ASEAN Harmonised Tariff Nomenclature (AHTN) 2017 into 2022 Jakarta, 22 April 2022: ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme and the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, Lao PDR, co-hosted a technical training workshop on transposing Lao PDR&rsquo;s tariff reduction schedule (TRS) from ASEAN Harmonised Tariff Nomenclature (AHTN) and Harmonised System (HS) 2017 into 2022.
The ASEAN Harmonized Tariff Nomenclature (AHTN), important for simplifying intra-ASEAN trade through the establishment of uniform tariff nomenclature, is structured around the World Customs Organisation&rsquo;s HS tariffs. These need periodic updating due to changes in tariff lines. Thus, for example, since the AHTN 2017, there has been a 5.27% increase in tariff lines, taking the total to 11,414 in the AHTN 2022. This increase in tariff lines results in the need to process the TRS transposition from AHTN 2017 into the AHTN 2022.
The four-day technical training focused on the process of TRS transposition and developing recommendations about which tariffs should be used in the case of merging tariff lines under different ASEAN free trade agreements (FTAs). The training was a follow-up to one focusing on the transposition of tariff commitments from AHTN&nbsp;2012 into 2017 held in 2021. Mr Ahmad Syaukat Romawi, an expert on this topic and former ASEAN Secretariat Official, led and facilitated this technical training workshop. Mr Somphone Phady, Acting Director of the Trade in Goods Division Department led the discussions with participating officials from the Lao PDR&rsquo;s Customs Department.
Following opening comments by Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA Director of Capacity Building, in which he highlighted ERIA&rsquo;s commitment to supporting ASEAN regional trade facilitation, the training began with an overview of AHTN 2022 and the technical method employed to modify HS Correlation Table 2017-2022 in relation to the ASEAN Trade in Goods Agreement (ATIGA) and ASEAN Australia New Zealand Free Trade Agreement (AANZFTA). Day two focused on the transposition of Lao PDR&rsquo;s Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) TRS from AHTN 2012 into AHTN 2017, with day three focusing on the ASEAN with China, Japan, Korea, and India Free Trade Agreements. The final day focused on the ASEAN agreement with Hong Kong as well as RCEP Product Specific Rules (PSR) from HS 2017 into HS 2022. &nbsp;
ERIA&rsquo;s ongoing Capacity Building Programme is supported by the Australian Government. ASEAN,Trade,Lao PDR            2022-04-22 22 April 2022 2202 lirpA 22 22-40-2202            RDP oaL,edarT,NAESA .tnemnrevoG nailartsuA eht yb detroppus si emmargorP gnidliuB yticapaC gniogno s;ouqsr&AIRE

Group";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-14";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:2132:"<p><strong>Jakarta, 14 April 2022</strong>: Dr Lili Yan Ing, ERIA&rsquo;s Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia met with Mr Reza Pahlevi, Director of APEC Negotiations and International Organizations of Ministry of Trade Indonesia from Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG), together with Mr John Drummond, Head of the Trade in Services Division of the OECD Trade and Agriculture Directorate and Dr Rupa Chanda, Director of Trade, Investment, and Innovation Division of UNESCAP, to discuss trade, investment, and industry, particularly focusing on the TIIWG Priority Issue Number 4&mdash;Digital Trade and Sustainable Global Value Chains (GVCs), as a follow-up from the previous First G20 TIIWG Meeting in Solo, 30-31 March 2022.</p><p>In the meeting, Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 TIIWG highlighted some points discussed and taken from the First G20 TIIWG Meeting: the importance of resilient global value chains and ensuring digital transformation shifting towards inclusive development. The G20 needs to ensure its roles in creating strategies for access to essential goods, including among others, health and medical supplies, critical inputs, or raw materials. Governments need to develop strategies to ensure investment in digital technologies and long-term solutions to improve supply chain resilience. In the digital transformation and digital trade, the G20 needs to ensure the development of industrial robots, automation, and artificial intelligent (AI); reduce the costs of adoption of technology, especially for developing countries; and bridge the skills gap by promoting efforts to improve preparedness for digital and AI technologies to achieve &lsquo;development for all&rsquo;. The meeting participants agreed that &nbsp;trade, investment, and industry must be resilient, sustainable, and inclusive.</p><p>The upcoming TIIWG is proposed to be held in Solo by the end of June this year with three priorities: WTO reform, response to the global pandemic, and sustainable investment. ERIA and other international organization will support the success of the upcoming working group meetings.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:137:"/uploads/articles/20220414/2022_april_eria-oecd-and-unescap-support-indonesia-g20-trade-investment-and-industry-working-group_800x450.png";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4675:"ERIA, OECD, and UNESCAP Support Indonesiaâ€™s G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group ERIA, OECD, and UNESCAP Support Indonesiaâ€™s G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group Jakarta, 14 April 2022: Dr Lili Yan Ing, ERIA&rsquo;s Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia met with Mr Reza Pahlevi, Director of APEC Negotiations and International Organizations of Ministry of Trade Indonesia from Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG), together with Mr John Drummond, Head of the Trade in Services Division of the OECD Trade and Agriculture Directorate and Dr Rupa Chanda, Director of Trade, Investment, and Innovation Division of UNESCAP, to discuss trade, investment, and industry, particularly focusing on the TIIWG Priority Issue Number 4&mdash;Digital Trade and Sustainable Global Value Chains (GVCs), as a follow-up from the previous First G20 TIIWG Meeting in Solo, 30-31 March 2022.
In the meeting, Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 TIIWG highlighted some points discussed and taken from the First G20 TIIWG Meeting: the importance of resilient global value chains and ensuring digital transformation shifting towards inclusive development. The G20 needs to ensure its roles in creating strategies for access to essential goods, including among others, health and medical supplies, critical inputs, or raw materials. Governments need to develop strategies to ensure investment in digital technologies and long-term solutions to improve supply chain resilience. In the digital transformation and digital trade, the G20 needs to ensure the development of industrial robots, automation, and artificial intelligent (AI); reduce the costs of adoption of technology, especially for developing countries; and bridge the skills gap by promoting efforts to improve preparedness for digital and AI technologies to achieve &lsquo;development for all&rsquo;. The meeting participants agreed that &nbsp;trade, investment, and industry must be resilient, sustainable, and inclusive.
The upcoming TIIWG is proposed to be held in Solo by the end of June this year with three priorities: WTO reform, response to the global pandemic, and sustainable investment. ERIA and other international organization will support the success of the upcoming working group meetings.             2022-04-14 14 April 2022 2202 lirpA 41 41-40-2202             .sgniteem puorg gnikrow gnimocpu eht fo sseccus eht troppus lliw noitazinagro lanoitanretni rehto dna AIRE .tnemtsevni elbaniatsus dna ,cimednap labolg eht ot esnopser ,mrofer OTW :seitiroirp eerht htiw raey siht enuJ fo dne eht yb oloS ni dleh eb ot desoporp si GWIIT gnimocpu ehT

,AIRE";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-04-26 16:45:41";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-04-26 Supports G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-21";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:1565:"<p><strong>Jakarta, 21 April 2022:</strong>&nbsp;A follow-up discussion on Indonesia&rsquo;s Group of Twenty (G20) presidency, particularly regarding the G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TII-WG) meeting, was the subject of a meeting attended by ERIA&rsquo;s Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia Dr Lili Yan Ing, Indonesia&rsquo;s Deputy Minister of Investment Dr Riyatno, Special Advisor to the Minister Dr Indra Darmawan, and Special Staff to the Minister on National Entrepreneurship Development Mr M. Pradana Indraputra. Also discussed at the meeting was the Investment Forum, to be held on 18 May 2022, and the High-Level Policy Dialogue, to be held in mid-July 2022.</p><p>Deputy Minister Dr Riyatno presented the theme of the Investment Forum and the overall arrangement to promote investment in renewable energy and 47 other priority areas. Also presented was the overall aim to achieve sustainable investment in energy transition, with Dr Ing emphasising the importance of sustainable investment, especially in relation to the supply-chain resilience in energy and across sectors. The Indonesia G20 expert team, led by Dr Ing and Professor Dani Rodrik, with Professors Gordon Hanson, Ishac Diwan, and Homi Kharas as members, reported on fostering investment and how best to finance renewable energy. Pradana Indraputra. Also discussed at the meeting was the Investment Forum, to be held on 18 May 2022, and the High-Level Policy Dialogue, to be held in mid-July 2022.
Deputy Minister Dr Riyatno presented the theme of the Investment Forum and the overall arrangement to promote investment in renewable energy and 47 other priority areas. Also presented was the overall aim to achieve sustainable investment in energy transition, with Dr Ing emphasising the importance of sustainable investment, especially in relation to the supply-chain resilience in energy and across sectors. The Indonesia G20 expert team, led by Dr Ing and Professor Dani Rodrik, with Professors Gordon Hanson, Ishac Diwan, and Homi Kharas as members, reported on fostering investment and how best to finance renewable energy. Dr Ing also called attention to the importance of keeping alive the three principles of : resilience, sustainability, and inclusiveness.

In the past, smart city initiatives may not have created desired impacts as these initiatives were limited in scope, focusing on physical-digital integration of the underlying systems of cities and of their citizens.<br />Smart information and communication technologies are finding their way into public administration. Today, there are numerous initiatives in the public sector, promising a new model for public services: smart government. Moreover, the government&rsquo;s ability to manage the potencies and assets owned through digital technology is the key to developing a smart city and smart village.<br />The webinar will highlight the strategy to implement digital transformation in government service to develop smart cities and smart villages. Besides that, this webinar will involve various stakeholders to discuss achieving digitalization success.<br />Goemart 2022 is an annual activity organized by Smart City and Community Innovation Center ITB which aims to create smart communities, smart people, smart villages, smart cities/districts, smart provinces in solving problems and global issues. Goesmart 2022 will take the theme of global recovery together with the title Goes to Smartization: Recover Together Recover Stronger. There will be 10 series of events that fully review the 9 policy briefs made by TF02 discussed with academics, industry, and organizations involved.</p><h2>Objectives of the Webinar</h2><ul><li>Introduce the policy areas in TF2 to the public.</li><li>Shows the condition of a specific topic in one policy area or more.</li><li>Discuss the challenges of a specific topic in one policy area or more.</li></ul><h2>Keynote Speakers</h2><ol><li>Bambang Susantono - Head of Authority IKN Nusantara, Topic: Building Digitalization Towards an Inclusive City</li><li>Anies Baswedan - Governor of DKI Jakarta| Lead Co-Chair U20, Topic: Optimized Digital Transformation In Government Services</li></ol><h2><br />Invited Speakers</h2><ol><li>Bima Arya Sugiarto &ndash; 11.45 am<br />Media : Zoom Meeting and Youtube Stream</p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="click here to register" href="/admin/article/edit/bit.ly/3rdgoesmart" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:67:"/uploads/articles/20220418/2022_april_g20-smart-cities_800x450.jpeg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6383:"[Event] Goesmart 2022 City Digitalization [Event] Goesmart 2022 City Digitalization In the &lsquo;industry 4.0&rsquo; era, the phenomenon of digitalization of smart cities has gained increasing prominence, as it has the potential to address the problem of resource optimization and the pressure of demand of the growing urban population. In the past, smart city initiatives may not have created desired impacts as these initiatives were limited in scope, focusing on physical-digital integration of the underlying systems of cities and of their citizens.Smart information and communication technologies are finding their way into public administration. Today, there are numerous initiatives in the public sector, promising a new model for public services: smart government. Moreover, the government&rsquo;s ability to manage the potencies and assets owned through digital technology is the key to developing a smart city and smart village.The webinar will highlight the strategy to implement digital transformation in government service to develop smart cities and smart villages. Besides that, this webinar will involve various stakeholders to discuss achieving digitalization success.Goemart 2022 is an annual activity organized by Smart City and Community Innovation Center ITB which aims to create smart communities, smart people, smart villages, smart cities/districts, smart provinces in solving problems and global issues. Goesmart 2022 will take the theme of global recovery together with the title Goes to Smartization: Recover Together Recover Stronger. There will be 10 series of events that fully review the 9 policy briefs made by TF02 discussed with academics, industry, and organizations involved.
Objectives of the Webinar

Introduce the policy areas in TF2 to the public.
Shows the condition of a specific topic in one policy area or more.
Discuss the challenges of a specific topic in one policy area or more.

Keynote Speakers

Bambang Susantono - Head of Authority IKN Nusantara, Topic: Building Digitalization Towards an Inclusive City
Anies Baswedan - Governor of DKI Jakarta| Lead Co-Chair U20, Topic: Optimized Digital Transformation In Government Services

Invited Speakers

Bima Arya Sugiarto &ndash; Chairman of APEKSITopic: Smart City as a Solution to Urban Problems
Toshio Obi - Director, APEC Digital Government ResearchCenter, Waseda University |Co-Chair and Researcher TF2 T20Topic: DX challenges for Digital Government and Smart City
Anbumozhi Venkatachalam - Senior Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) | Co-Chair and Researcher TF2 T20Topic: Standardization Road Maps for Smart Cities and Digital Governance
Arry Akhmad Arman &ndash; Institut Teknologi Bandung | SCCIC ITB | Researcher TF2 T20Topic: Development of Smart City Global Framework
F&aacute;bio Duarte - Principal Research Scientist, Senseable City Lab LecturerTopic: Building Digital Cities with Transformative Technology

Moderator
I.G.B Baskara Nugraha - Researcher SCCIC-ITB

ERIA&rsquo;s Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia, Dr Lili Yan Ing, had a constructive discussion with Professor Dani Rodrik, President of the International Economic Association (IEA) and Dr Vera Songwe, Executive Secretary of the UN Economic Commission for Africa (ECA), on emerging issues in economic recovery and the important role that the G20 can take in addressing them.
Dr Ing, Prof Rodrik, and Dr Songwe agree that levels of economic recovery across countries are uneven, starting from health, trade, investment, to overall economy. ECA provided an and their efforts to support quick recovery, particularly for middle- and low-income countries who need it most. Prof Rodrik and Dr Ing welcomed the LSF and will consider representing it to the G20 Presidency of Indonesia. Dr Ing also highlighted current global issues, especially challenges of developing countries with low tax revenue over GDP and high debt over GDP that provide them very limited spaces for fiscal interventions which have restrained their recovery.
Dr Ing and Prof Rodrik work together with Dr Songwe and other experts to provide insights to Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 presidency. The expert team will publish a report titled &lsquo;Indonesia&rsquo;s G20: New Normal, New Technologies, New Financing&rsquo;&nbsp; by June this year consisting of 12 policy notes on the three priority issues &ndash;economic recovery, digital transformation, and new energy-- the G20 must address. All three institutions agreed to continue coordination of the efforts regarding the G20 and to strengthen their relationships.             2022-04-13 13 April 2022 2202 lirpA 31 31-40-2202             .spihsnoitaler rieht nehtgnerts ot dna 02G eht gnidrager stroffe eht fo noitanidrooc eunitnoc ot deerga snoitutitsni eerht llA .sserdda tsum 02G eht --ygrene wen dna ,noitamrofsnart latigid ,yrevocer cimonoce;hsadn& seussi ytiroirp eerht eht no seton ycilop 21 fo gnitsisnoc raey siht enuJ yb ;psbn&;ouqsr&gnicnaniF weN ,seigolonhceT weN ,lamroN weN :02G s;ouqsr&aisenodnI;ouqsl& deltit troper a hsilbup lliw maet trepxe ehT .ycnediserp 02G s;ouqsr&aisenodnI ot sthgisni edivorp ot strepxe rehto dna ewgnoS rD htiw rehtegot krow kirdoR forP dna gnI rD

This is particularly the case in the Asian region which will comprise the bulk of incremental energy demand and CO2 emissions. Thus, the clean use of fossil fuels and Carbon Capture, Utilisation and Storage (CCUS) will be extremely important to decarbonise emissions. A recent study conducted by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) on the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)&rsquo;s decarbonisation scenarios showed that the marginal abatement cost for achieving net-zero emissions by 2050 will be much more expensive compared with the 2070 net-zero emissions case.</p><p>CCUS is a crucial element of the clean energy transition as it is the only technology that contributes both to directly reducing emissions in high energy intensity economic sectors and to removing CO2 to balance emissions that cannot be avoided.&nbsp; Another way to reduce emission is through carbon recycling. After CO2 is captured, it is used to create&nbsp;new materials and products. Instead of just sequestering the CO2, the CO2 will be utilized to make everything from fuel, concrete, and shoes, to cleaning products, plastics, and food. This allows us to recycle the emissions and create a circular carbon economy.</p><p>However, the deployment of CCUS will require appropriate supporting policies and investment. Thus, technical experts will need to understand the technical aspect of CCUS and its technologies to help decision-makers to decide on appropriate energy policies to support the development and deployment of CCUS.</p><p>Taking the opportunity of Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 Chairmanship, this side event workshop hosted by Asia CCUS Network and the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR) of the Republic of Indonesia are very pleased to invite all stakeholders to participate in an online workshop on &lsquo;Commercializing CCS/CCUS: Making Technologies Affordable&rsquo;. The workshop will promote knowledge-sharing on the cost structure and range of expected costs of CCUS, joint project demonstration and policy frameworks for supporting the development and deployment of CCS/CCUS. As part of this workshop, we seek potential collaborators for a joint demonstration project (coal power plant&nbsp;+ CCUS) with the participation and support of interested G20 countries.&nbsp;</p><p>The 2022 G20 Indonesia Presidency Energy Transition pillar includes the main topic of &lsquo;Global Cleaner Energy Systems and Just Transitions&rsquo; that aims at &lsquo;achieving global deal to accelerate energy transition&rsquo;. In this regards, multiple pathways will need to be adopted including the innovative and artificial technology such as CCUS will play important role for carbon sinks and help to decarbonise emissions in identified hard to abated economic sectors.</p><p>This workshop will provide new insights into how to make CCS/CCUS affordable to all countries, especially in the developing world. This side event workshop will help escalate the role of CCS/CCUS as part of the just process of low carbon energy transition in developing countries which shall foster the G20 energy transition agenda.</p><p>In addition, this workshop aims to support G20 Members to understand the different pathways through the application of artificial carbon sink technology such as CCS/CCUS in the low carbon energy transition context, while pursuing and strengthening the implementation of the previous 2021 G20 Italian action plan that includes ensuring access to clean energy for all, especially in developing countries.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Wednesday, 13 April 2022</li><li>Time: 4 PM- 6:05 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7))</li><li>RSVP:&nbsp;<a title="Click here to register" Now</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:113:"/uploads/articles/20220408/2022-april-making-ccs-ccus-affordable-enabling-ccus-deployment-in-g20-and-beyond-1.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:10:"G20,Energy";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:12461:"[Event] Making CCS/CCUS Affordable: Enabling CCUS Deployment in G20 and Beyond [Event] Making CCS/CCUS Affordable: Enabling CCUS Deployment in G20 and Beyond Even when all the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) are revised and implemented, coal, oil and natural gas will still occupy over half of the total global primary energy supply. This is particularly the case in the Asian region which will comprise the bulk of incremental energy demand and CO2 emissions. Thus, the clean use of fossil fuels and Carbon Capture, Utilisation and Storage (CCUS) will be extremely important to decarbonise emissions. A recent study conducted by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) on the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)&rsquo;s decarbonisation scenarios showed that the marginal abatement cost for achieving net-zero emissions by 2050 will be much more expensive compared with the 2070 net-zero emissions case.
CCUS is a crucial element of the clean energy transition as it is the only technology that contributes both to directly reducing emissions in high energy intensity economic sectors and to removing CO2 to balance emissions that cannot be avoided.&nbsp; Another way to reduce emission is through carbon recycling. After CO2 is captured, it is used to create&nbsp;new materials and products. Instead of just sequestering the CO2, the CO2 will be utilized to make everything from fuel, concrete, and shoes, to cleaning products, plastics, and food. This allows us to recycle the emissions and create a circular carbon economy.
However, the deployment of CCUS will require appropriate supporting policies and investment. Thus, technical experts will need to understand the technical aspect of CCUS and its technologies to help decision-makers to decide on appropriate energy policies to support the development and deployment of CCUS.
Taking the opportunity of Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 Chairmanship, this side event workshop hosted by Asia CCUS Network and the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR) of the Republic of Indonesia are very pleased to invite all stakeholders to participate in an online workshop on &lsquo;Commercializing CCS/CCUS: Making Technologies Affordable&rsquo;. The workshop will promote knowledge-sharing on the cost structure and range of expected costs of CCUS, joint project demonstration and policy frameworks for supporting the development and deployment of CCS/CCUS. As part of this workshop, we seek potential collaborators for a joint demonstration project (coal power plant&nbsp;+ CCUS) with the participation and support of interested G20 countries.&nbsp;
The 2022 G20 Indonesia Presidency Energy Transition pillar includes the main topic of &lsquo;Global Cleaner Energy Systems and Just Transitions&rsquo; that aims at &lsquo;achieving global deal to accelerate energy transition&rsquo;. In this regards, multiple pathways will need to be adopted including the innovative and artificial technology such as CCUS will play important role for carbon sinks and help to decarbonise emissions in identified hard to abated economic sectors.
This workshop will provide new insights into how to make CCS/CCUS affordable to all countries, especially in the developing world. This side event workshop will help escalate the role of CCS/CCUS as part of the just process of low carbon energy transition in developing countries which shall foster the G20 energy transition agenda.
In addition, this workshop aims to support G20 Members to understand the different pathways through the application of artificial carbon sink technology such as CCS/CCUS in the low carbon energy transition context, while pursuing and strengthening the implementation of the previous 2021 G20 Italian action plan that includes ensuring access to clean energy for all, especially in developing countries.

Indonesiaâ€™s G20 Amidst Rising Trade Tensions";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-02-18";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"2";s:7:"content";s:8265:"<p><strong>By Dr Lili Yan Ing, Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia Region:&nbsp;</strong>Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 presidency in 2022 is crucial to the global recovery from the health and economic crisis wrought by COVID-19.&nbsp; With rising protectionism and increasing trade tensions around the world, how ready is Indonesia to address these issues?</p><p>In February 2020, the US and China signed the Economic and Trade Agreement - the so-called &lsquo;Phase One&rsquo; trade deal &ndash; which many have predicted will only create further trade diversions in global trade. And indeed US - China trade (now including technology) tensions have been escalating instead of decreasing, putting pressure on smaller economies to choose between the two global powers.</p><p>Even after the agreement was signed, Beijing&rsquo;s dual circulation plan promotes self-reliance, indigenous innovation, and settling more trade deals in Renminbi. At the same time, the US strategy is equally (or worse) escalating tensions with its policies of realigning supply chains by &lsquo;friend-shoring&rsquo;, accompanied by policies mandating that key technologies must be produced at home or by designated US allies. The largest and most innovative US electric vehicle company has even started controlling its own supply chains.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p>So, what solutions can Indonesia offer during its G20 presidency?</p><p>Let&rsquo;s start by reviewing Indonesia&rsquo;s foreign trade policy, where it stands, and what it can offer the G20. East Asia, including Southeast Asian countries grouped as ASEAN (including Indonesia), has been achieving high economic growth based on trade and Investment. ASEAN has been very active in promoting trade and investment as well as forming trade agreements to facilitate this including the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) in 1992 and the ASEAN+1 FTAs with its main trading partners which was mostly concluded in 2010.</p><p>Recently, ASEAN and its five main trading partners concluded the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). The RCEP came into effect on 1 January 2022 as it has already reached the quorum with ratification by 11 member countries:&nbsp; Brunei, Cambodia, Laos, Thailand, Vietnam, Singapore, and all non-ASEAN signatories (Australia, China, Japan, Korea, and New Zealand). Indonesia has not ratified the agreement yet. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>The RCEP is the largest economic bloc in the world. Even without India, in 2021, the countries in the RCEP account for 31% of the world&rsquo;s population, 31% of global GDP, 27% of trade, and 33% of foreign direct investment (FDI).&nbsp; By comparison, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (or TPP) without the US (now so-called the CPTPP) represents only 7% of the world&rsquo;s population, 13% of global GDP, 15% of trade, and 20% of FDI.</p><p>While ASEAN joins the RCEP, will ASEAN (including Indonesia) join the CPTPP? Most ASEAN countries are less likely to join the CPTPP in the absence of the US due to at least three main reasons.</p><p>First, economics: ASEAN countries would face high adjustment costs with relatively smaller benefits compared to joining the RCEP. Second, domestic political economy: the CPTPP contains more ambitious provisions that require broader, deeper, and shorter time for adoption into domestic laws including state-owned enterprises, intellectual property rights, competition policy, and labor and environmental standards.</p><p>Last, the benefit of RCEP is that even though it doesn&rsquo;t call for liberalization at the same level, scope, or depth of commitment as the CTPP, its impacts on the economies of member countries, and indeed on the world economy, will be massive. At the same time, the RCEP will incentivize supply chains in the region while also being sensitive to political conditions and levels of development in member countries. So, ASEAN&rsquo;s current top priorities are the implementation of the RCEP and the ASEAN-EU trade agreement (either bilaterally or as a unified ASEAN).</p><p>Does this mean that ASEAN (Indonesia) stands for China over the US? Of course not. ASEAN will retain is neutrality and stand for neither of them. At this moment, neither the US nor China listens to trade economists as they keep creating trade diversions by any means. But at least they have learned that protectionism does not work.&nbsp;</p><p>When the US decided to increase tariff rates on USD 350 billion worth of imports from China, it was aiming to block imports from China. But just less than two years later, the results are the other way around. In 2021, US exports to China were USD 179 billion and imports from China USD 576 billion resulting in a USD 397 billion trade deficit in goods with China and USD - the largest in 30 years.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>The same result applied to Chinese&rsquo;s efforts to ban Australia&rsquo;s exports. China implicitly banned all imports from Australia, except iron ore which is needed for China&rsquo;s steel industry. China tried to source inputs from other countries thus creating trade diversions. However, while Australia lost USD 4,4 billion in its trade with China, it has been able to access new markets worth USD 4 billion.&nbsp; Eventually, trade coercions China created vis a vis Australia resulted in increased iron ore prices, resulting in an increase of 10% of Australia&rsquo;s total exports in 2021.</p><p>Ultimately, prolonged US-China trade and technology tensions will raise uncertainties that will be translated into costs for everyone, most of all, for the American and Chinese people.&nbsp;&nbsp; US-China tensions further intensify the urgency of strengthening the rules-based multilateral trading system.</p><p>To address these issues, Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 chairmanship should pursue Trade and Investment (Indonesia is now proposing Trade, Investment, and Industry) by emphasizing the following:</p><p>First, Indonesia should obtain G20 commitments to eliminate unnecessary regulations and customs clearances while at the same time increasing surveillance on specific health supplies, medicines, and medical appliances. The pandemic has taught us how health and the economy are strongly connected. &nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>Second, G20 countries should commit to strengthening the multilateral trading system to serve its three main functions: Trade Rules, Negotiations, and Dispute Settlement. These need to be separate commitments &ndash; not tied to one another. One of the key functions of the WTO is the dispute settlement mechanism; it is a must to ensure that it is well functioning.&nbsp;</p><p>Third, Indonesia should encourage G20 members to implement the Doha Development Agenda agreed back in 2001. At the same time, in response to new issues in trade, Indonesia can encourage members to pursue an open plurilateral agreement mechanism to move forward in the negotiation on difficult issues in the WTO.</p><p>In conclusion, while useful, forming mega-FTAs like the RCEP and the CPTPP with pro-trade middle powers is a stopgap solution, not a substitute for a well-functioning multilateral trading system. If the global powers keep exercising their powers, the markets and customers can too. We can learn from the renewable energy market on how people-driven power can stir the whole policy and political landscape.</p><p><em>This opinion piece was written by ERIA&#039;s Lead Advisor and Senior Economist, Dr Lili Yan Ing . It has been published in&nbsp;<a href="https://www.thejakartapost.com/opinion/2022/02/24/indonesias-challenge-in-reviving-g20-relevance-toward-global-recovery.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">The Jakarta Post</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="https://www.manilatimes.net/2022/02/22/opinion/columns/indonesias-challenge-in-reviving-the-g20-for-global-economic-recovery/1833764" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">The Manila Times</a>.&nbsp;C<a title="Subscribe to ERIA FRAMES" href="http://eepurl.com/bSCVl1" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">lick here</a>&nbsp;to subscribe to the monthly newsletter.</em></p><p><em>Disclaimer: The views expressed are purely those of the authors and may not in any circumstances be regarded as stating an official position of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia.</em></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:65:"/uploads/articles/20220218/istock-480531658_singapore_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:15589:"[Op-ed] Indonesiaâ€™s G20 Amidst Rising Trade Tensions [Op-ed] Indonesiaâ€™s G20 Amidst Rising Trade Tensions By Dr Lili Yan Ing, Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia Region:&nbsp;Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 presidency in 2022 is crucial to the global recovery from the health and economic crisis wrought by COVID-19.&nbsp; With rising protectionism and increasing trade tensions around the world, how ready is Indonesia to address these issues?
In February 2020, the US and China signed the Economic and Trade Agreement - the so-called &lsquo;Phase One&rsquo; trade deal &ndash; which many have predicted will only create further trade diversions in global trade. And indeed US - China trade (now including technology) tensions have been escalating instead of decreasing, putting pressure on smaller economies to choose between the two global powers.
Even after the agreement was signed, Beijing&rsquo;s dual circulation plan promotes self-reliance, indigenous innovation, and settling more trade deals in Renminbi. At the same time, the US strategy is equally (or worse) escalating tensions with its policies of realigning supply chains by &lsquo;friend-shoring&rsquo;, accompanied by policies mandating that key technologies must be produced at home or by designated US allies. The largest and most innovative US electric vehicle company has even started controlling its own supply chains.&nbsp; &nbsp;
So, what solutions can Indonesia offer during its G20 presidency?
Let&rsquo;s start by reviewing Indonesia&rsquo;s foreign trade policy, where it stands, and what it can offer the G20. East Asia, including Southeast Asian countries grouped as ASEAN (including Indonesia), has been achieving high economic growth based on trade and Investment. ASEAN has been very active in promoting trade and investment as well as forming trade agreements to facilitate this including the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) in 1992 and the ASEAN+1 FTAs with its main trading partners which was mostly concluded in 2010.
Recently, ASEAN and its five main trading partners concluded the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). The RCEP came into effect on 1 January 2022 as it has already reached the quorum with ratification by 11 member countries:&nbsp; Brunei, Cambodia, Laos, Thailand, Vietnam, Singapore, and all non-ASEAN signatories (Australia, China, Japan, Korea, and New Zealand). Indonesia has not ratified the agreement yet. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The RCEP is the largest economic bloc in the world. Even without India, in 2021, the countries in the RCEP account for 31% of the world&rsquo;s population, 31% of global GDP, 27% of trade, and 33% of foreign direct investment (FDI).&nbsp; By comparison, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (or TPP) without the US (now so-called the CPTPP) represents only 7% of the world&rsquo;s population, 13% of global GDP, 15% of trade, and 20% of FDI.
While ASEAN joins the RCEP, will ASEAN (including Indonesia) join the CPTPP? Most ASEAN countries are less likely to join the CPTPP in the absence of the US due to at least three main reasons.
First, economics: ASEAN countries would face high adjustment costs with relatively smaller benefits compared to joining the RCEP. Second, domestic political economy: the CPTPP contains more ambitious provisions that require broader, deeper, and shorter time for adoption into domestic laws including state-owned enterprises, intellectual property rights, competition policy, and labor and environmental standards.
Last, the benefit of RCEP is that even though it doesn&rsquo;t call for liberalization at the same level, scope, or depth of commitment as the CTPP, its impacts on the economies of member countries, and indeed on the world economy, will be massive. At the same time, the RCEP will incentivize supply chains in the region while also being sensitive to political conditions and levels of development in member countries. So, ASEAN&rsquo;s current top priorities are the implementation of the RCEP and the ASEAN-EU trade agreement (either bilaterally or as a unified ASEAN).
Does this mean that ASEAN (Indonesia) stands for China over the US? Of course not. ASEAN will retain is neutrality and stand for neither of them. At this moment, neither the US nor China listens to trade economists as they keep creating trade diversions by any means. But at least they have learned that protectionism does not work.&nbsp;
When the US decided to increase tariff rates on USD 350 billion worth of imports from China, it was aiming to block imports from China. But just less than two years later, the results are the other way around. In 2021, US exports to China were USD 179 billion and imports from China USD 576 billion resulting in a USD 397 billion trade deficit in goods with China and USD - the largest in 30 years.&nbsp;&nbsp;
The same result applied to Chinese&rsquo;s efforts to ban Australia&rsquo;s exports. China implicitly banned all imports from Australia, except iron ore which is needed for China&rsquo;s steel industry. China tried to source inputs from other countries thus creating trade diversions. However, while Australia lost USD 4,4 billion in its trade with China, it has been able to access new markets worth USD 4 billion.&nbsp; Eventually, trade coercions China created vis a vis Australia resulted in increased iron ore prices, resulting in an increase of 10% of Australia&rsquo;s total exports in 2021.
Ultimately, prolonged US-China trade and technology tensions will raise uncertainties that will be translated into costs for everyone, most of all, for the American and Chinese people.&nbsp;&nbsp; US-China tensions further intensify the urgency of strengthening the rules-based multilateral trading system.
To address these issues, Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 chairmanship should pursue Trade and Investment (Indonesia is now proposing Trade, Investment, and Industry) by emphasizing the following:
First, Indonesia should obtain G20 commitments to eliminate unnecessary regulations and customs clearances while at the same time increasing surveillance on specific health supplies, medicines, and medical appliances. The pandemic has taught us how health and the economy are strongly connected. &nbsp;&nbsp;
Second, G20 countries should commit to strengthening the multilateral trading system to serve its three main functions: Trade Rules, Negotiations, and Dispute Settlement. These need to be separate commitments &ndash; not tied to one another. One of the key functions of the WTO is the dispute settlement mechanism; it is a must to ensure that it is well functioning.&nbsp;
Third, Indonesia should encourage G20 members to implement the Doha Development Agenda agreed back in 2001. At the same time, in response to new issues in trade, Indonesia can encourage members to pursue an open plurilateral agreement mechanism to move forward in the negotiation on difficult issues in the WTO.
In conclusion, while useful, forming mega-FTAs like the RCEP and the CPTPP with pro-trade middle powers is a stopgap solution, not a substitute for a well-functioning multilateral trading system. If the global powers keep exercising their powers, the markets and customers can too. We can learn from the renewable energy market on how people-driven power can stir the whole policy and political landscape.
This opinion piece was written by ERIA's Lead Advisor and Senior Economist, Dr Lili Yan Ing . It has been published in&nbsp;The Jakarta Post, and&nbsp;The Manila Times.&nbsp;Click here&nbsp;to subscribe to the monthly newsletter.
