Policy Responses to Unlock the Lockdown in Cambodia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-06-08";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"6";s:7:"content";s:2297:"<p><strong>Cambodia, 8 June 2021:</strong>&nbsp;Hosted jointly by the Cambodian Ministry of Commerce, ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme held an online workshop on &lsquo;Unlocking the Lockdown: Alignment of Domestic and Regional Policies&rsquo;&nbsp;on 8 June. Thirty-seven officials from a range of ministries attended the workshop that was supported by Australia.</p><p>Led by Prof Shandre Thangavelu from the University of Adelaide&rsquo;s Institute of International Trade and the Jeffrey Cheah Institute of Southeast Asia, Sunway University, the workshop focused on key policies issues for managing the post-pandemic recovery and sequencing strategies to emerge from lockdown. Divided into two sessions, the first session focused on the&nbsp;impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on ASEAN including gaps, challenges and misalignments of domestic policy - with a focus on the importance of addressing policy coordination between the public good and private good to mitigate the pandemic shock. The second session discussed structural transformation and relief packages to restore the resilience of the global value chain (GVC).&nbsp;</p><p>H.E. RATH Saravuth, Director General of International Trade at Cambodia&rsquo;s Ministry of Commerce opened the session by highlighting the importance of ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building workshop to equip Cambodian officials with a better understanding of the pandemic&rsquo;s impact at the regional and global level. He also discussed Cambodian priorities for exploring policy responses around economic recovery strategies, especially with upcoming major events, including the 13th ASEM Summit at the end of 2021, the 40th ASEAN Summit and related meetings for the Cambodian ASEAN Chairmanship, in 2022 in mind.&nbsp;</p><p>Mr Anthony Samson, Second Secretary, Australian Embassy in Cambodia also delivered opening comments, noting Australia&rsquo;s commitment to support the ASEAN Comprehensive Recovery Framework (ACRF) Initiative by strengthening bilateral and regional cooperation with the ASEAN Member States. Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA&rsquo;s Director of Capacity Building, moderated the workshop. He reaffirmed ERIA&rsquo;s strong support for pandemic crisis mitigation at the regional level through a series of capacity-building activities.&nbsp;</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:114:"/uploads/articles/20210608/2021_june_identifying-policy-responses-to-unlock-the-lockdown-in-cambodia_2_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:8:"Cambodia";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4859:"Identifying Policy Responses to Unlock the Lockdown in Cambodia Identifying Policy Responses to Unlock the Lockdown in Cambodia Cambodia, 8 June 2021:&nbsp;Hosted jointly by the Cambodian Ministry of Commerce, ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme held an online workshop on &lsquo;Unlocking the Lockdown: Alignment of Domestic and Regional Policies&rsquo;&nbsp;on 8 June. Thirty-seven officials from a range of ministries attended the workshop that was supported by Australia.
Led by Prof Shandre Thangavelu from the University of Adelaide&rsquo;s Institute of International Trade and the Jeffrey Cheah Institute of Southeast Asia, Sunway University, the workshop focused on key policies issues for managing the post-pandemic recovery and sequencing strategies to emerge from lockdown. Divided into two sessions, the first session focused on the&nbsp;impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on ASEAN including gaps, challenges and misalignments of domestic policy - with a focus on the importance of addressing policy coordination between the public good and private good to mitigate the pandemic shock. The second session discussed structural transformation and relief packages to restore the resilience of the global value chain (GVC).&nbsp;
H.E. RATH Saravuth, Director General of International Trade at Cambodia&rsquo;s Ministry of Commerce opened the session by highlighting the importance of ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building workshop to equip Cambodian officials with a better understanding of the pandemic&rsquo;s impact at the regional and global level. He also discussed Cambodian priorities for exploring policy responses around economic recovery strategies, especially with upcoming major events, including the 13th ASEM Summit at the end of 2021, the 40th ASEAN Summit and related meetings for the Cambodian ASEAN Chairmanship, in 2022 in mind.&nbsp;
Mr Anthony Samson, Second Secretary, Australian Embassy in Cambodia also delivered opening comments, noting Australia&rsquo;s commitment to support the ASEAN Comprehensive Recovery Framework (ACRF) Initiative by strengthening bilateral and regional cooperation with the ASEAN Member States. Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA&rsquo;s Director of Capacity Building, moderated the workshop. The workshop discussed key policy gaps for Lao PDR as it undertakes structural transformation in response to the pandemic and post-pandemic periods.&nbsp;</p><p>Attended by 25 officials from a wide range of ministries and agencies, the workshops were led Dr Shandre Thangavelu from the University of Adelaide&rsquo;s Institute of International Trade and the Jeffrey Cheah Institute of Southeast Asia, Sunway University. In his welcoming remarks, Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA&rsquo;s Director of Capacity Building, highlighted the importance of structural transformation to address competitiveness, with key issues revolving around institutional and human capital reform.&nbsp;He also thanked the Centre for Development Policy Research as co-host.</p><p>The first session of the workshop elaborated upon the main aspects of vulnerability analysis: the identification of policy gaps, structural gaps and risk analysis. The second session focused on structural transformation strategy and the need to design a policy framework that balances the public and private good for overcoming the disruptive effects of the pandemic. Strategies and challenges to mitigate supply and demand activities in the global value chain were discussed in the third session, whilst the final session focused on the importance of regionalism, such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership to recover from the pandemic.</p><p>Participants raised questions ranging from available mechanisms to monitor behavioural changes in response to the impact of the pandemic, strategies relating to human resources, labour, open borders and food security.&nbsp;</p><p>Deputy Director-General Sisavanh Didaravong closed the workshop by expressing her gratitude to ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme, and the Australian Government for supporting it, noting the emergence of valuable policy recommendations and the identification of policy responses raised in the workshop.&nbsp;</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:123:"/uploads/articles/20210531/2021_may_identifying-policy-gaps-to-undertake-structural-transformation-in-lao-pdr_1_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4919:"Identifying Policy Gaps to Undertake Structural Transformation in Lao PDR Identifying Policy Gaps to Undertake Structural Transformation in Lao PDR Vientiane, 19 May 2021:&nbsp;Hosted jointly by the Ministry of Planning and Investment&rsquo;s Centre for Development Policy Research (CDR) of Lao PDR, ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme held a two-day online workshop, &lsquo;Vulnerability Analysis: Challenges and Policy Gaps in the Structural Transformation of Lao PDR&rsquo;, on 18-19 May. The workshop discussed key policy gaps for Lao PDR as it undertakes structural transformation in response to the pandemic and post-pandemic periods.&nbsp;
Attended by 25 officials from a wide range of ministries and agencies, the workshops were led Dr Shandre Thangavelu from the University of Adelaide&rsquo;s Institute of International Trade and the Jeffrey Cheah Institute of Southeast Asia, Sunway University. In his welcoming remarks, Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA&rsquo;s Director of Capacity Building, highlighted the importance of structural transformation to address competitiveness, with key issues revolving around institutional and human capital reform.&nbsp;He also thanked the Centre for Development Policy Research as co-host.
The first session of the workshop elaborated upon the main aspects of vulnerability analysis: the identification of policy gaps, structural gaps and risk analysis. The second session focused on structural transformation strategy and the need to design a policy framework that balances the public and private good for overcoming the disruptive effects of the pandemic. Strategies and challenges to mitigate supply and demand activities in the global value chain were discussed in the third session, whilst the final session focused on the importance of regionalism, such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership to recover from the pandemic.
Participants raised questions ranging from available mechanisms to monitor behavioural changes in response to the impact of the pandemic, strategies relating to human resources, labour, open borders and food security.&nbsp;

Its aim was to (1) measure the general knowledge of older people about COVID-19, (2) compare the welfare and health status of older people before and during the COVID-19 pandemic, (3) understand their difficulties during the COVID-19 pandemic, (4) monitor the assistance they receive, and (5) identify the policies required to mitigate the impact on them.&nbsp;</p><p>The results revealed that more than half of older people saw their income fall, particularly those who depended on income from work or their children&rsquo;s income. Significantly more older people received government support compared with before the pandemic. One in six older persons reported a deterioration in their health during the pandemic, while most older people maintained their social interaction despite the pandemic. The government is encouraged to strengthen its efforts to develop the support system for older people to ensure realisation of the vision set out in the National Strategy for Older People.</p><h2>The Appendix</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:73:"/uploads/articles/20210225/cover-upload-older-people-indonesia-25-feb.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3593:"Older People and COVID-19 in Indonesia Older People and COVID-19 in Indonesia The phone survey of older people and coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in Indonesia was conducted as a joint project by ERIA, Bappenas, and SurveyMETER. Its aim was to (1) measure the general knowledge of older people about COVID-19, (2) compare the welfare and health status of older people before and during the COVID-19 pandemic, (3) understand their difficulties during the COVID-19 pandemic, (4) monitor the assistance they receive, and (5) identify the policies required to mitigate the impact on them.&nbsp;
The results revealed that more than half of older people saw their income fall, particularly those who depended on income from work or their children&rsquo;s income. Significantly more older people received government support compared with before the pandemic. One in six older persons reported a deterioration in their health during the pandemic, while most older people maintained their social interaction despite the pandemic. The government is encouraged to strengthen its efforts to develop the support system for older people to ensure realisation of the vision set out in the National Strategy for Older People.
The Indonesian version available at SurveyMeter website:&nbsp;Bahasa Indonesia

;psbn&.meht no tcapmi eht etagitim ot deriuqer seicilop eht yfitnedi )5( dna ,eviecer yeht ecnatsissa eht rotinom )4( ,cimednap 91-DIVOC eht gnirud seitluciffid rieht dnatsrednu )3( ,cimednap 91-DIVOC eht gnirud dna erofeb elpoep redlo fo sutats htlaeh dna eraflew eht erapmoc )2( ,91-DIVOC tuoba elpoep redlo fo egdelwonk lareneg eht erusaem )1( ot saw mia stI .RETEMyevruS dna ,saneppaB ,AIRE yb tcejorp tnioj a sa detcudnoc saw aisenodnI ni )91-DIVOC( esaesid surivanoroc dna elpoep redlo fo yevrus enohp ehT aisenodnI ni 91-DIVOC dna elpoeP redlO aisenodnI ni 91-DIVOC dna elpoeP redlO";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-05-20 17:44:52";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-05-20 17:45:22";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";N;s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:136;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6265";s:12:"article_type";s:8:"articles";s:3:"uri";s:95:"the-impact-of-covid-19-on-global-production-networks-evidence-from-japanese-multinational-firms";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:96:"The Impact of COVID-19 on Global Production Networks: Evidence from Japanese Multinational Firms";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-03-26";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"3";s:7:"content";s:1805:"<p>Using aggregate-level data on Japanese multinational corporations (MNCs) in major host countries and regions, this paper investigates the impact of COVID-19 on global production and supply chains with a focus on East Asia. I use the numbers of COVID-19 cases and deaths as measures of the impact of the pandemic. I find that the pandemic had substantial impacts on the performance (sales, employment, and investment) of Japanese MNCs and global supply chains (exports to Japan and exports to third countries) in Q1&ndash;Q3 2020. China recovered quickly in Q2 and grew in Q3, whilst the countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the rest of the world had still not fully recovered in Q3 2020. Importantly, lockdown and containment policies in host countries had large negative impacts on the sales and employment of Japanese MNCs. In contrast, I did not find positive effects of economic support policies on firm performance. Interestingly, whilst the firm expectations and business plans of Japanese MNCs were negatively affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, their business confidence increased with strong overall government policy responses in host countries in Q1 2020.</p><p><em>This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).</em></p><p class="pdf"><a title="The Impact of COVID-19 on Global Production Networks: Evidence from Japanese Multinational Firms" href="/uploads/media/discussion-papers/ERIA-Research-on-COVID-19/The-Impact-of-COVID-19-on-Global-Production-Networks_Evidence-from-Japanese-Multinational-Firms.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">The Impact of COVID-19 on Global Production Networks: Evidence from Japanese Multinational Firms</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:58:"/uploads/articles/20210326/eria-dp-2020-37-no364_cover.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3357:"The Impact of COVID-19 on Global Production Networks: Evidence from Japanese Multinational Firms The Impact of COVID-19 on Global Production Networks: Evidence from Japanese Multinational Firms Using aggregate-level data on Japanese multinational corporations (MNCs) in major host countries and regions, this paper investigates the impact of COVID-19 on global production and supply chains with a focus on East Asia. I use the numbers of COVID-19 cases and deaths as measures of the impact of the pandemic. I find that the pandemic had substantial impacts on the performance (sales, employment, and investment) of Japanese MNCs and global supply chains (exports to Japan and exports to third countries) in Q1&ndash;Q3 2020. China recovered quickly in Q2 and grew in Q3, whilst the countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the rest of the world had still not fully recovered in Q3 2020. Importantly, lockdown and containment policies in host countries had large negative impacts on the sales and employment of Japanese MNCs. In contrast, I did not find positive effects of economic support policies on firm performance. Interestingly, whilst the firm expectations and business plans of Japanese MNCs were negatively affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, their business confidence increased with strong overall government policy responses in host countries in Q1 2020.
This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).

COVID-19 Pandemic and the World Trade Network";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-03-29";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"3";s:7:"content";s:1348:"<p>Global trade is expected to suffer a significant contraction as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Did the relative importance of countries in the world trade network change as a result of the pandemic? The answer to this question is particularly important for Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries because of their strong trade linkages with China, where the COVID-19 virus originated. This paper examines how the world trade network has changed since the COVID-19 pandemic, with a particular focus on ASEAN countries. Tracking the changes in centrality from January 2000 to June 2020, we find no evidence that centrality changed significantly after the pandemic started for most ASEAN countries. Our results suggest that the relative importance of the ASEAN countries in the world trade network is unchanged and will remain unchanged even after the pandemic.</p><p><em>This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).</em></p><p class="pdf"><a title="The COVID-19 Pandemic and the World Trade Network" href="/uploads/media/discussion-papers/ERIA-Research-on-COVID-19/The-COVID-19-Pandemic-World-Trade-Network.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">The COVID-19 Pandemic and the World Trade Network</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:60:"/uploads/articles/20210329/eria-dp-2020-38-no365_cover-1.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:2457:"The COVID-19 Pandemic and the World Trade Network The COVID-19 Pandemic and the World Trade Network Global trade is expected to suffer a significant contraction as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. This paper examines how the world trade network has changed since the COVID-19 pandemic, with a particular focus on ASEAN countries. and Supply Shocks of COVID-19 and International Production Networks: Evidence from Japanâ€™s Machinery Trade";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-03-29";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"3";s:7:"content";s:2287:"<p><strong>Abstract:&nbsp;</strong>This paper investigated the impacts of COVID-19 on international production networks in machinery sectors by shedding light on negative supply shocks, negative demand shocks, and positive demand shocks. Specifically, we examined changes in trade in the periods of falling trade during the first wave of COVID-19 using Japan&rsquo;s machinery trade at the most disaggregated level and decomposed them into two intensive margins, i.e. the quantity effect and the price effect, and two extensive margins, i.e. the entry effect and the exit effect. Our empirical results demonstrated that i) trade relationships for parts and components are robust, and international production networks are almost intact, so far; ii) the intensive margin, mostly the negative quantity effect, induces the largest negative effects in the transport equipment sector amongst four machinery sectors; iii) positive demand shocks for specific products that are related to teleworking, disinfection, and stay-home activities partially explain sectoral differences; iv) direct negative supply shocks from China, suggested by a negative quantity effect and a positive price effect, exist in February 2020, with possible indirect negative supply shocks and substitution of source countries; and v) negative demand shocks are confirmed from negative quantity and price effects in many cases. As of October 2020, Japan&rsquo;s machinery trade seems to have largely recovered. If the COVID-19 pandemic lasts long, however, prolonged negative demand shocks would hurt production networks in East Asia.</p><p><em>This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).</em></p><p class="pdf"><a title="Demand and Supply Shocks of COVID-19 and International Production Networks: Evidence from Japan&rsquo;s Machinery Trade" href="/uploads/media/discussion-papers/ERIA-Research-on-COVID-19/Demand-and-Supply-Shocks-of-COVID-19-and-International-Production-Networks_Evidence-from-Japan%E2%80%99s-Machinery-Trade.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Demand and Supply Shocks of COVID-19 and International Production Networks: Evidence from Japan&rsquo;s Machinery Trade</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:58:"/uploads/articles/20210329/eria-dp-2020-39-no366_cover.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4287:"Demand and Supply Shocks of COVID-19 and International Production Networks: Evidence from Japanâ€™s Machinery Trade Demand and Supply Shocks of COVID-19 and International Production Networks: Evidence from Japanâ€™s Machinery Trade Abstract:&nbsp;This paper investigated the impacts of COVID-19 on international production networks in machinery sectors by shedding light on negative supply shocks, negative demand shocks, and positive demand shocks. Specifically, we examined changes in trade in the periods of falling trade during the first wave of COVID-19 using Japan&rsquo;s machinery trade at the most disaggregated level and decomposed them into two intensive margins, i.e. the quantity effect and the price effect, and two extensive margins, i.e. the entry effect and the exit effect. Our empirical results demonstrated that i) trade relationships for parts and components are robust, and international production networks are almost intact, so far; ii) the intensive margin, mostly the negative quantity effect, induces the largest negative effects in the transport equipment sector amongst four machinery sectors; iii) positive demand shocks for specific products that are related to teleworking, disinfection, and stay-home activities partially explain sectoral differences; iv) direct negative supply shocks from China, suggested by a negative quantity effect and a positive price effect, exist in February 2020, with possible indirect negative supply shocks and substitution of source countries; and v) negative demand shocks are confirmed from negative quantity and price effects in many cases. As of October 2020, Japan&rsquo;s machinery trade seems to have largely recovered. If the COVID-19 pandemic lasts long, however, prolonged negative demand shocks would hurt production networks in East Asia.
This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).

Evidence from the Emissions of Air Pollutants</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:53:"/uploads/articles/20210331/dp-2020-40-no367_cover.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:2787:"How Is the Asian Economy Recovering from the COVID-19 Pandemic? Evidence from the Emissions of Air Pollutants How Is the Asian Economy Recovering from the COVID-19 Pandemic? Evidence from the Emissions of Air Pollutants This study empirically examines how economic and social activities in Asia were affected by the COVID-19 pandemic by using the emissions amounts of various air pollutants to represent those activities. Review of the emissions data suggests that from 2019 to 2020, the amount of emitted air pollutants decreased in most subnational regions in Asia. Data also show how economic and social activities have restarted in some regions; regression analyses are used to uncover the regions that restarted early. Regional characteristics are identified by employing a remotely sensed land cover dataset (i.e. ESALC) and OpenStreetMap. Results reveal that for Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) members, economic and social activities in cropland, industrial estates, accommodations, restaurants, education, and public services still have not returned to normal.
This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).

COVID-19 Pandemic, Air Transport Perturbation, and Sector Impacts in ASEAN Plus Five:  A Multiregional Inputâ€“Output Inoperability Analysis";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-04-16";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:1937:"<p>This study simulates the sector impacts of demand-side perturbations on air transport sectors due to the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on ASEAN members plus Australia, China, Japan, the Republic of Korea, and New Zealand. This study involves (i) the generation of a multiregional input&ndash;output table from the latest Global Trade Analysis Project data, (ii) a network analysis to determine the importance of the air transport industry in each country, (iii) multiplier and linkages analyses, (iv) determinations of sector impacts from demand-side perturbations on air transport sectors due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and (v) simulation of the effect of fiscal and monetary measures to mitigate the pandemic&rsquo;s impact. This study demonstrates that the aviation industry is a key sector in domestic and regional economic activities, and the reduction in air transport consumer demand due to the pandemic is estimated to cause gross domestic product (GDP) reductions from 0.4% to 2.1%. Government intervention, through fiscal and monetary policies, has, however, mitigated severe impact, moderating GDP and value-added losses. Thus, a viable policy prescription for the aviation industry is of utmost importance.</p><p><em>This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).</em></p><p class="pdf"><a title="The COVID-19 Pandemic, Air Transport Perturbation, and Sector Impacts in ASEAN Plus Five: A Multiregional Input&ndash;Output Inoperability Analysis" href="/uploads/media/discussion-papers/ERIA-Research-on-COVID-19/The-COVID-19-Pandemic%2C-Air-Transport-Perturbation%2C-and-Sector-Impacts-in-ASEAN-Plus-Five.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">The COVID-19 Pandemic, Air Transport Perturbation, and Sector Impacts in ASEAN Plus Five:&nbsp; A Multiregional Input&ndash;Output Inoperability Analysis</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:52:"/uploads/articles/20210416/eria-dp-2021-01_cover.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3737:"The COVID-19 Pandemic, Air Transport Perturbation, and Sector Impacts in ASEAN Plus Five:  A Multiregional Inputâ€“Output Inoperability Analysis The COVID-19 Pandemic, Air Transport Perturbation, and Sector Impacts in ASEAN Plus Five:  A Multiregional Inputâ€“Output Inoperability Analysis This study simulates the sector impacts of demand-side perturbations on air transport sectors due to the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on ASEAN members plus Australia, China, Japan, the Republic of Korea, and New Zealand. This study involves (i) the generation of a multiregional input&ndash;output table from the latest Global Trade Analysis Project data, (ii) a network analysis to determine the importance of the air transport industry in each country, (iii) multiplier and linkages analyses, (iv) determinations of sector impacts from demand-side perturbations on air transport sectors due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and (v) simulation of the effect of fiscal and monetary measures to mitigate the pandemic&rsquo;s impact. This study demonstrates that the aviation industry is a key sector in domestic and regional economic activities, and the reduction in air transport consumer demand due to the pandemic is estimated to cause gross domestic product (GDP) reductions from 0.4% to 2.1%. Government intervention, through fiscal and monetary policies, has, however, mitigated severe impact, moderating GDP and value-added losses. Thus, a viable policy prescription for the aviation industry is of utmost importance.
This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).

the salience of reducing service link costs for overcoming the economic and health challenges emanating from COVID-19, we examine the implications of the pandemic for services trade in the original group of ASEAN+6 countries that began negotiating the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership agreement. Our analysis reveals that with the exception of the Philippines and Viet Nam for services exports, and Cambodia and India for services imports, up to half of total services trade for all other sample countries could be adversely affected by the pandemic. Our analysis reveals that with the exception of the Philippines and Viet Nam for services exports, and Cambodia and India for services imports, up to half of total services trade for all other sample countries could be adversely affected by the pandemic. In the absence of bilateral services trade data for 2020, we proxy the impact of COVID-19 on services trade using bilateral data on announced greenfield investment in services sectors from fDi Markets. Structural gravity estimates suggest that a 1% increase in COVID-19-related deaths in the source country may have reduced ASEAN+6 bilateral greenfield investment by US$0.15 million in 2020 relative to the corresponding value in 2019.
This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).

Effect of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Global Production Sharing in East Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-04-21";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:1601:"<p>This paper examines the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on global production sharing in ASEAN Member States. Product-level analysis &ndash; on hard disk drives, air conditioners, microwaves, televisions, washing machines, and automotive parts &ndash; is undertaken to examine trade patterns between January 2019 and October/November 2020. The key finding suggests that the pandemic caused parts shortages, but this effect has been short-lived. There is no strong evidence that multi-national enterprises have altered their supply chains or means of sourcing parts and components in response to the pandemic. There is some indication that multi-national enterprises are moving away from China, but whether this reflects a &lsquo;COVID-19 effect&rsquo; or the trade war between the United States and China is not clear. COVID-19, a once-in-a-century event, may not alone be a compelling reason to restructure supply chain management relating to global production sharing, which has been a structural phenomenon driving economic globalisation.</p><p><em>This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).</em></p><p class="pdf"><a title="The Effect of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Global Production Sharing in East Asia" href="/uploads/media/discussion-papers/ERIA-Research-on-COVID-19/The-Effect-of-the-COVID-19-Pandemic-on-Global-Production-Sharing-in-East-Asia.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">The Effect of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Global Production Sharing in East Asia</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:54:"/uploads/articles/20210421/eria-dp-2021-03_cover-1.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:2947:"The Effect of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Global Production Sharing in East Asia The Effect of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Global Production Sharing in East Asia This paper examines the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on global production sharing in ASEAN Member States. Product-level analysis &ndash; on hard disk drives, air conditioners, microwaves, televisions, washing machines, and automotive parts &ndash; is undertaken to examine trade patterns between January 2019 and October/November 2020. The key finding suggests that the pandemic caused parts shortages, but this effect has been short-lived. There is no strong evidence that multi-national enterprises have altered their supply chains or means of sourcing parts and components in response to the pandemic. There is some indication that multi-national enterprises are moving away from China, but whether this reflects a &lsquo;COVID-19 effect&rsquo; or the trade war between the United States and China is not clear. COVID-19, a once-in-a-century event, may not alone be a compelling reason to restructure supply chain management relating to global production sharing, which has been a structural phenomenon driving economic globalisation.

study examines if COVID-19 has worsened socio-economic inequalities across provinces in Indonesia, and if it has affected the spatial disparity in provincial-level socio-economic indicators. Secondary provincial-level data are used from BPS for March 2015 to March 2020. Results indicate that provinces with more COVID-19 cases tend to have increased inequality in urban areas, but inequality in rural areas decreases, as measured by the Gini Index. Macroeconomic Conjectures Based on the SARS Epidemic Could the COVID-19 Crisis Affect Remittances and Labour Supply in ASEAN Economies? Macroeconomic Conjectures Based on the SARS Epidemic Debates on resilience to economic shocks in the ASEAN region focus on what policymakers can do to mitigate negative impacts associated with financial-economic crises. The COVID-19 pandemic has made it clear that the region is also vulnerable to health-economic crises. This study applies a difference-in-difference strategy to data from the 2003 SARS epidemic to shed light on how a global pandemic can affect labour supply and remittances in ASEAN economies. Findings suggest that even a relatively short-lived epidemic can have long-lasting effects on labour supply.&nbsp;
This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).

Market Responses to Government COVID-19 Pandemic Interventions: Empirical Evidence from South-East and East Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-04-29";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:1778:"<p>This study investigates the impact of various government interventions on the spread of COVID-19 as well as stock markets in South-East and East Asia. It finds that stricter interventions &ndash; including gathering restrictions, public event cancellations, and mask requirements &ndash; helped mitigate the severity of the pandemic significantly in the region. Total border closures had a moderate effect on flattening COVID-19 spread, especially during the onset of the pandemic. Other policies, such as school closures or stay-at-home orders, worked effectively later in the pandemic. The study also shows evidence of herding behaviours in regional stock markets during the pandemic. School closures, gathering restrictions, stay-at-home orders, domestic travelling bans, robust testing policies, and government income support programmes tended to reduce herding behaviour. More stock market integration is found during the onset of the pandemic, compared to the periods before and later in the pandemic, implying the short-term impact of a sudden shock from COVID-19.</p><p><em>This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).</em></p><p class="pdf"><a title="Financial Market Responses to Government COVID-19 Pandemic Interventions: Empirical Evidence from South-East and East Asia&nbsp;" href="/uploads/media/discussion-papers/ERIA-Research-on-COVID-19/Financial-Market-Responses-to-Government-COVID-19-Pandemic-Interventions_Empirical-Evidence-from-South-East-and-East-Asia.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Financial Market Responses to Government COVID-19 Pandemic Interventions: Empirical Evidence from South-East and East Asia&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:52:"/uploads/articles/20210429/eria-dp-2021-07_cover.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3291:"Financial Market Responses to Government COVID-19 Pandemic Interventions: Empirical Evidence from South-East and East Asia Financial Market Responses to Government COVID-19 Pandemic Interventions: Empirical Evidence from South-East and East Asia This study investigates the impact of various government interventions on the spread of COVID-19 as well as stock markets in South-East and East Asia. It finds that stricter interventions &ndash; including gathering restrictions, public event cancellations, and mask requirements &ndash; helped mitigate the severity of the pandemic significantly in the region. Total border closures had a moderate effect on flattening COVID-19 spread, especially during the onset of the pandemic. Other policies, such as school closures or stay-at-home orders, worked effectively later in the pandemic. The study also shows evidence of herding behaviours in regional stock markets during the pandemic. School closures, gathering restrictions, stay-at-home orders, domestic travelling bans, robust testing policies, and government income support programmes tended to reduce herding behaviour. More stock market integration is found during the onset of the pandemic, compared to the periods before and later in the pandemic, implying the short-term impact of a sudden shock from COVID-19.
This research was conducted as a part of the project &lsquo;ERIA Research on Covid-19&rsquo; at the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA).

17:22:07";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";N;s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:147;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6246";s:12:"article_type";s:8:"articles";s:3:"uri";s:45:"preparing-to-unlock-the-lockdown-with-lao-pdr";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:45:"Preparing to Unlock the Lockdown with Lao PDR";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-05-17";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"5";s:7:"content";s:2466:"<p><strong>6 May 2021:</strong>&nbsp;ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme held an online workshop,&nbsp;&lsquo;<em>Unlocking the Lockdown: Alignment of Domestic and Regional Policies&rsquo;</em>&nbsp;on 6 May. Hosted jointly by the Ministry of Planning and Investment&rsquo;s Centre for Development Policy Research (CDR), 31 officials from a wide range of ministries and agencies participated in the workshop. The workshop was led by Dr Shandre Thangavelu from the University of Adelaide&rsquo;s Institute of International Trade and the Jeffrey Cheah Institute of Southeast Asia, Sunway University.</p><p>Divided into two sessions, the first session focused on the&nbsp;<em>impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on ASEAN, looking at the gaps, challenges and alignments of domestic policy, with a focus on the importance of addressing policy coordination between the national and sub-national levels to mitigate the pandemic shock</em>. The second session discussed&nbsp;<em>relief, stimulus, and the potential for global value chain (GVC)</em>&nbsp;<em>recovery in East Asia</em>, looking at strategy for maintaining market access and opportunities. The workshop also identified trends for the post-recovery period and their economic implications.</p><p>Dr Sitthiroth Rasphone, Acting Director-General of the Centre for Development Policy Research, in his opening comments for the workshop, highlighted the importance of this workshop to support Lao PDR in mitigating the pandemic effects by formulating a good policy response and producing constructive actions for post-economic recovery in the long-term. Ms Hannah Wurf, Second Secretary, Australian Embassy in Lao PDR, delivered opening remarks on behalf of the Australian Government, which funds the Capacity Building Program. She highlighted how this workshop supports the officials in defining strategies to mitigate the pandemic effects.She also mentioned the importance of regionalism especially with the establishment of RCEP.</p><p>Deputy Director-General Sisavanh Didaravong closed the workshop by expressing her utmost gratitude for this workshop and the clear guidance it provided for identifying policy responses for the post-COVID-19 economic recovery. Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA&rsquo;s Director of Capacity Building, moderated the workshop. He noted ERIA&rsquo;s continuous commitment to promote ASEAN economic integration by delivering analytical research and policy recommendations across the region.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:95:"/uploads/articles/20210517/2021_may_preparing-to-unlock-the-lockdown-with-lao-pdr-1_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:5037:"Preparing to Unlock the Lockdown with Lao PDR Preparing to Unlock the Lockdown with Lao PDR 6 May 2021:&nbsp;ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme held an online workshop,&nbsp;&lsquo;Unlocking the Lockdown: Alignment of Domestic and Regional Policies&rsquo;&nbsp;on 6 May. Hosted jointly by the Ministry of Planning and Investment&rsquo;s Centre for Development Policy Research (CDR), 31 officials from a wide range of ministries and agencies participated in the workshop. The workshop was led by Dr Shandre Thangavelu from the University of Adelaide&rsquo;s Institute of International Trade and the Jeffrey Cheah Institute of Southeast Asia, Sunway University.
Divided into two sessions, the first session focused on the&nbsp;impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on ASEAN, looking at the gaps, challenges and alignments of domestic policy, with a focus on the importance of addressing policy coordination between the national and sub-national levels to mitigate the pandemic shock. The second session discussed&nbsp;relief, stimulus, and the potential for global value chain (GVC)&nbsp;recovery in East Asia, looking at strategy for maintaining market access and opportunities. The workshop also identified trends for the post-recovery period and their economic implications.
Dr Sitthiroth Rasphone, Acting Director-General of the Centre for Development Policy Research, in his opening comments for the workshop, highlighted the importance of this workshop to support Lao PDR in mitigating the pandemic effects by formulating a good policy response and producing constructive actions for post-economic recovery in the long-term. Ms Hannah Wurf, Second Secretary, Australian Embassy in Lao PDR, delivered opening remarks on behalf of the Australian Government, which funds the Capacity Building Program. She highlighted how this workshop supports the officials in defining strategies to mitigate the pandemic effects.She also mentioned the importance of regionalism especially with the establishment of RCEP.
Deputy Director-General Sisavanh Didaravong closed the workshop by expressing her utmost gratitude for this workshop and the clear guidance it provided for identifying policy responses for the post-COVID-19 economic recovery. Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA&rsquo;s Director of Capacity Building, moderated the workshop. During the meeting, they discussed the elements of the Network, such as the vision, mission, membership, structure, secretariat, and advisory group.&nbsp;
At the Fourteenth East Asia Summit Energy Ministers Meeting (14th EAS EMM) held on 20 November 2020, attended by the ministers and senior officials responsible for energy from the EAS participating countries that are also ASEAN Member States (AMS), Australia, the People&rsquo;s Republic of China, India, Japan, the Republic of Korea, New Zealand, the Russian Federation, and the United States, the ministers welcomed the continuous efforts by the EAS Energy Cooperation Task Force (ECTF) to foster EAS energy cooperation towards a sustainable energy future.
They were pleased with the implementation of concrete initiatives under the three ECTF work streams as well as the other initiatives involving the promotion of hydrogen society, mobility decarbonisation, natural gas, and CCUS. On the initiative to promote CCUS and carbon recycling, the ministers noted the importance of CCUS and carbon recycling in supporting the goals of decarbonisation, recovery, and economic growth. The ministers welcomed the cooperation initiative led by Japan and ERIA to establish the &lsquo;Asia CCUS Network&rsquo;, which is expected to realise the partnership to help implement knowledge and experience sharing and research activities in the EAS region.             2021-04-28 28 April 2021 1202 lirpA 82 82-40-1202             .noiger SAE eht ni seitivitca hcraeser dna gnirahs ecneirepxe dna egdelwonk tnemelpmi pleh ot pihsrentrap eht esilaer ot detcepxe si hcihw ,;ouqsr&krowteN SUCC aisA;ouqsl& eht hsilbatse ot AIRE dna napaJ yb del evitaitini noitarepooc eht democlew sretsinim ehT .htworg cimonoce dna ,yrevocer ,noitasinobraced fo slaog eht gnitroppus ni gnilcycer nobrac dna SUCC fo ecnatropmi eht deton sretsinim eht ,gnilcycer nobrac dna SUCC etomorp ot evitaitini eht nO .SUCC dna ,sag larutan ,noitasinobraced ytilibom ,yteicos negordyh fo noitomorp eht gnivlovni sevitaitini rehto eht sa llew sa smaerts krow FTCE eerht eht rednu sevitaitini etercnoc fo noitatnemelpmi eht htiw desaelp erew yehT

V for the details) provides services and support to ensure the smooth functioning of the Asia CCUS Network to realise its vision and mission statement. The Network is composed of:

Members: Policymakers from Governments of ASEAN and EAS region countries can participate as members of the Asia CCUS Network.
Supporting members: a) public and private companies interested in CCUS activities and business in the EAS region; b) academia including universities, research institutes, and think tanks interested in conducting CCUS technical, economic, and legal studies in the EAS region; c) financial institutions and commercial banks interested in supporting CCUS business financially; d) regional and international organisations, forums, and initiatives relating to CCUS.

All of the above Network members and supporting members share the vision and support the mission of the Asia CCUS Network. To realize the vision and accomplish the mission, any activities among Network members and supporting members are to be conducted by voluntary basis and are not to be obliged.
They are encouraged to share their experiences and knowledge in their respective countries and within their jurisdiction of any development of CCUS &ndash; either policy formulation or practical pilot projects. Furthermore, a Network secretariat will conduct research studies on CCUS with technical assistance from the supporting members.
Structure of Asia CCUS Network
The secretariat facilitated by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) with support from the Advisory Group (see Sec. V for the details) provides services and support to ensure the smooth functioning of the Asia CCUS Network to realise its vision and mission statement. To implement the Asia CCUS Network, the following organic structure with roles and responsibilities for each party involved is proposed:

Become a Supporting Member
If you are interested to become a member of the Asia CCUS Network, you need to agree to the following conditions:


You are from:


public and private companies, or


academia, or


financial institutions and commercial banks, or


regional and international organizations




You share the vision and support the mission of Asia CCUS Network


Click the button below and fill the form.

They were pleased with the implementation of concrete initiatives under the three ECTF work streams as well as the other initiatives involving the promotion of hydrogen society, mobility decarbonisation, natural gas, and CCUS. On the initiative to promote CCUS and carbon recycling, the ministers noted the importance of CCUS and carbon recycling in supporting the goals of decarbonisation, recovery, and economic growth. The ministers welcomed the cooperation initiative led by Japan and ERIA to establish the &lsquo;Asia CCUS Network&rsquo;, which is expected to realise the partnership to help implement knowledge and experience sharing and research activities in the EAS region.
Vision
Through collaboration and cooperation on the development and deployment of CCUS in the Asia region, the Network will contribute to the decarbonisation of the region
Mission
Facilitate deployment of CCUS in the EAS region through the following activities:



Promote knowledge sharing through holding an annual forum, conferences, workshops, and meetings.
Conduct research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS
Hold capacity building training workshops.

13:19:27";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";N;s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:151;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6175";s:12:"article_type";s:8:"articles";s:3:"uri";s:59:"transposition-of-tariff-commitments-in-preparation-for-rcep";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:59:"Transposition of Tariff Commitments in Preparation for RCEP";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-04-06";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:2333:"<p><strong>&nbsp;Vientiane, 6 April 2021:</strong>&nbsp;A two-day online training and discussion around the&nbsp;<em>Transposition of Tariff Commitment from ASEAN Harmonized Tariff Nomenclature (AHTN)</em>&nbsp;<em>2012 into 2017&nbsp;</em>was held virtually on 5-6 April 2021<em>.&nbsp;</em>This activity, for Lao Government officials<em>,&nbsp;</em>is to support preparations for the anticipated implementation of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).</p><p>The training was organised by ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme following a request from Mme Khemmani Pholsena, former Minister at the Ministry of Industry and Commerce (MOIC). Co-hosted by the MOIC, the training was facilitated by expert on this topic and former ASEAN Secretariat official, Mr Ahmad Syaukat Romawi. Ten government officials - from various departments including the Department of Foreign Trade Policy, Import and Export, and Customs, actively involved in the transposition process, participated in this online event.</p><p>Opening remarks was conveyed by Mr Santisouk Phounesvath, Deputy Director General at the MOIC&rsquo;s Department of Foreign Trade Policy. Mr Santisouk Phounesvath noted the importance of this training for Lao PDR to gain a better understanding of the methodology as well as policy decisions concerning how and when to merge tariff lines with different tariff rates. Mr Somphone Phady, Deputy Director at the Trade in Goods Division Department led the discussion with the participating government officials. Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA Director of Capacity Building, in his opening comments, highlighted ERIA&rsquo;s commitment to support Lao PDR government officials through its mandate to support ASEAN regional trade facilitation.</p><p>On the first day of the training, the trainer explained the four options of the WTO methodology for applying tariff rates when merging tariff lines with different tariff rates. Participants also focused on how to copy the data in Lao PDR&rsquo;s RCEP Tariff Reduction (TRS) into the Modified AHTN Correlation Table. On the second day, the trainer examined the transposition of RCEP Product Specific Rules (PSR) from the information of Harmonised System (HS) 2012 into 2017.</p><p>ERIA&rsquo;s ongoing Capacity Building Programme is supported by the Australian Government.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:112:"/uploads/articles/20210406/2021_april_transposition-of-tariff-commitments-in-preparation-for-rcep_2_800x450.jpeg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:26:"ASEAN,Lao PDR,Trade,tariff";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4871:"Transposition of Tariff Commitments in Preparation for RCEP Transposition of Tariff Commitments in Preparation for RCEP &nbsp;Vientiane, 6 April 2021:&nbsp;A two-day online training and discussion around the&nbsp;Transposition of Tariff Commitment from ASEAN Harmonized Tariff Nomenclature (AHTN)&nbsp;2012 into 2017&nbsp;was held virtually on 5-6 April 2021.&nbsp;This activity, for Lao Government officials,&nbsp;is to support preparations for the anticipated implementation of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).
The training was organised by ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme following a request from Mme Khemmani Pholsena, former Minister at the Ministry of Industry and Commerce (MOIC). Co-hosted by the MOIC, the training was facilitated by expert on this topic and former ASEAN Secretariat official, Mr Ahmad Syaukat Romawi. Ten government officials - from various departments including the Department of Foreign Trade Policy, Import and Export, and Customs, actively involved in the transposition process, participated in this online event.
Opening remarks was conveyed by Mr Santisouk Phounesvath, Deputy Director General at the MOIC&rsquo;s Department of Foreign Trade Policy. Mr Santisouk Phounesvath noted the importance of this training for Lao PDR to gain a better understanding of the methodology as well as policy decisions concerning how and when to merge tariff lines with different tariff rates. Mr Somphone Phady, Deputy Director at the Trade in Goods Division Department led the discussion with the participating government officials. Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA Director of Capacity Building, in his opening comments, highlighted ERIA&rsquo;s commitment to support Lao PDR government officials through its mandate to support ASEAN regional trade facilitation.
On the first day of the training, the trainer explained the four options of the WTO methodology for applying tariff rates when merging tariff lines with different tariff rates. Participants also focused on how to copy the data in Lao PDR&rsquo;s RCEP Tariff Reduction (TRS) into the Modified AHTN Correlation Table. On the second day, the trainer examined the transposition of RCEP Product Specific Rules (PSR) from the information of Harmonised System (HS) 2012 into 2017.
ERIA&rsquo;s ongoing Capacity Building Programme is supported by the Australian Government. The webinar was led by Prof. Shandre Thangavelu of the University of Adelaide&rsquo;s Institute of International Trade and the Jeffrey Cheah Institute of Southeast Asia, Sunway University. Twenty-five government officials from various ministries and state institutions participated.</p><p>Hosted by the Economic Research Institute for Industry and Trade, Ministry of Industry and Commerce, opening comments were given by Deputy Director-General Viengsavang Thipphavong. The Deputy Director-General highlighted the importance of the workshop to support Lao PDR&rsquo;s socio-economic development. Ms Hannah Wurf, Second Secretary for Economics and Trade, Australian Embassy, Lao PDR, in her opening remarks stated that servicification is crucial as the strategy for Lao PDR in the post-recovery period and with world digitalisation.&nbsp; The webinar was hosted by Mr Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building of ERIA.</p><p>The workshop was divided into two sessions. The first was on <em>Cities, Services and GVC: Case of ASEAN LDCs and Lao PDR</em>, which examined how services and manufacturing activities are intertwined in the global value chain (GVC) framework and their importance to contextualise its strategy for less developed countries in ASEAN Member States in leveraging the production of goods and services.</p><p>The second session, <em>New Growth Path for ASEAN: Gaps, Challenges, and Opportunities</em>, focused on the opportunities for building up efficiencies and connectivity within ASEAN cities linkages and networks. It also highlighted the importance of reform in digital and institutional infrastructure to enable ASEAN&rsquo;s less developed countries to transform key activities in GVC and leverage economic development.</p><p>Participants raised questions about the strategy for services and manufacturing development and the role of digitalisation, human capital, and innovation to promote inclusive economic growth in the post-recovery economic activity in Lao PDR.</p><p>ERIA&rsquo;s on-going Capacity Building Programme is supported by the Australian Government.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:122:"/uploads/articles/20210326/2021_march_looking-ahead-to-opportunities-in-services-in-the-post-pandemic-period_1_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4809:"Looking Ahead to Opportunities in Services in the Post-Pandemic Period Looking Ahead to Opportunities in Services in the Post-Pandemic Period Vientiane, 22 March 2021: On 22 March, ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme held an online workshop, Services, Urban Amenities and Global Value Chain: New Growth Paths. The webinar was led by Prof. Shandre Thangavelu of the University of Adelaide&rsquo;s Institute of International Trade and the Jeffrey Cheah Institute of Southeast Asia, Sunway University. Twenty-five government officials from various ministries and state institutions participated.
Hosted by the Economic Research Institute for Industry and Trade, Ministry of Industry and Commerce, opening comments were given by Deputy Director-General Viengsavang Thipphavong. The Deputy Director-General highlighted the importance of the workshop to support Lao PDR&rsquo;s socio-economic development. Ms Hannah Wurf, Second Secretary for Economics and Trade, Australian Embassy, Lao PDR, in her opening remarks stated that servicification is crucial as the strategy for Lao PDR in the post-recovery period and with world digitalisation.&nbsp; The webinar was hosted by Mr Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building of ERIA.
The workshop was divided into two sessions. The first was on Cities, Services and GVC: Case of ASEAN LDCs and Lao PDR, which examined how services and manufacturing activities are intertwined in the global value chain (GVC) framework and their importance to contextualise its strategy for less developed countries in ASEAN Member States in leveraging the production of goods and services.
The second session, New Growth Path for ASEAN: Gaps, Challenges, and Opportunities, focused on the opportunities for building up efficiencies and connectivity within ASEAN cities linkages and networks. It also highlighted the importance of reform in digital and institutional infrastructure to enable ASEAN&rsquo;s less developed countries to transform key activities in GVC and leverage economic development.
Participants raised questions about the strategy for services and manufacturing development and the role of digitalisation, human capital, and innovation to promote inclusive economic growth in the post-recovery economic activity in Lao PDR.
ERIA&rsquo;s on-going Capacity Building Programme is supported by the Australian Government.             2021-03-26 26 March 2021 1202 hcraM 62 62-30-1202             .tnemnrevoG nailartsuA eht yb detroppus si emmargorP gnidliuB yticapaC gniog-no s;ouqsr&AIRE

and PHAD Present Findings of the 2018 Longitudinal Study on Ageing and Health in Viet Nam";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-03-04";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"3";s:7:"content";s:2081:"<p><strong>Jakarta, 4 March 2021</strong>: In December 2020, the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and&nbsp;<a href="https://www.phad.org/en/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">the Institute of Population, Health and Development (PHAD)</a>&nbsp;launched the report <a href="/publications/ageing-and-health-in-viet-nam/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer"><em>Ageing and Health in Viet Nam: Findings of the 2018 Longitudinal Study on Ageing and Health in Viet Nam (LSAHV)</em></a><em>.</em>&nbsp;Through this set of infographics, ERIA and PHAD present the basic demographic indicators to understand the status of ageing in Viet Nam population.</p><p>The LSAHV is designed to (1) investigate the health status and well-being, as well as their correlates, of Vietnamese people aged 60 years and above; and (2) assess the determinants of health status and transitions in health status and overall well-being. The data generated from the 2018 baseline survey and the succeeding waves will provide a wealth of information that will allow for a deeper understanding of ageing in Viet Nam. The full report of the 2018 LSAHV can be downloaded from:&nbsp;<a href="/publications/ageing-and-health-in-viet-nam/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://www.eria.org/publications/ageing-and-health-in-viet-nam/</a></p><p><iframe style="border: 1px solid #CCC; border-width: 1px; margin-bottom: 5px; max-width: 100%;" src="//www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/key/2ZEugKHlnKONyT" width="668" height="714" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" data-mce-fragment="1"> </iframe></p><div style="margin-bottom: 5px;"><strong> <a title="LSAHV Infographics_EN" href="//www.slideshare.net/InstituteofPopulatio/lsahv-infographicsen" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">LSAHV Infographics_EN</a> </strong> from <strong><a href="https://www.slideshare.net/InstituteofPopulatio" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Institute of Population, Health and Development</a></strong></div>";s:10:"image_name";s:144:"/uploads/articles/20210304/2021_march_eria-and-phad-present-findings-of-the-2018-longitudinal-study-on-ageing-and-health-in-viet-nam_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:22:"ageing,health,Viet Nam";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:2707:"ERIA and PHAD Present Findings of the 2018 Longitudinal Study on Ageing and Health in Viet Nam ERIA and PHAD Present Findings of the 2018 Longitudinal Study on Ageing and Health in Viet Nam Jakarta, 4 March 2021: In December 2020, the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and&nbsp;the Institute of Population, Health and Development (PHAD)&nbsp;launched the report Ageing and Health in Viet Nam: Findings of the 2018 Longitudinal Study on Ageing and Health in Viet Nam (LSAHV).&nbsp;Through this set of infographics, ERIA and PHAD present the basic demographic indicators to understand the status of ageing in Viet Nam population.
The LSAHV is designed to (1) investigate the health status and well-being, as well as their correlates, of Vietnamese people aged 60 years and above; and (2) assess the determinants of health status and transitions in health status and overall well-being. The data generated from the 2018 baseline survey and the succeeding waves will provide a wealth of information that will allow for a deeper understanding of ageing in Viet Nam. The full report of the 2018 LSAHV can be downloaded from:&nbsp;https://www.eria.org/publications/ageing-and-health-in-viet-nam/
