.serohs lacol dnoyeb sessenisub rieht gnidnapxe nehw decaf segnellahc dna seitinutroppo eht no ,sreep ssenisub dna strepxe morf naelg ot stnapicitrap dewolla snoissucsid lenap lareveS .sEMSM morf pihsredael thguoht dna gnirahs lacitcarp sa llew sa seussi edart cimonoce-orcam neewteb ecnalab a dedivorp timmuS ehT .sredrob ssorca worg sEMS pleh ot ti egarevel ot woh dna edart latigid no sthgisni niag ot dna ymonoce latigid eht ssucsid ot rotces etavirp eht dna sEMS rehtegot thguorb timmuS ymonocE latigiD EMS eht ,labolG ot lacoL morF;psbn&demehT;psbn&:9102 rebotcO 61 ,eropagniS timmuS ymonocE latigiD EMS eht ni ymonocE latigiD ssucsiD rotceS etavirP dna sEMS timmuS ymonocE latigiD EMS eht ni ymonocE latigiD ssucsiD rotceS etavirP dna sEMS";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2020-04-07 15:03:48";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2020-04-07 18:42:18";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";N;s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:210;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"5573";s:12:"article_type";s:8:"articles";s:3:"uri";s:110:"academics-city-officials-private-sector-and-international-organisations-discuss-issues-related-to-smart-cities";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:113:"Academics, City Officials, Private Sector, and International Organisations Discuss Issues Related to Smart Cities";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2020-02-29";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2020";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"2";s:7:"content";s:3048:"<p><strong>Salem, 29 February 2020</strong>: What are the current plans and performance indicators for a smart city &ndash; and what are the perceived benefits of a smart city? These are some of the issues that a diverse range of academics, city officials, the private sector, and representatives of international organisations, grappled with at a workshop and symposium titled &lsquo;Driving Sustainability Innovations Through Smart Cities&rsquo; held at Periyar University, Salem, India, from 27 to 29 February.</p><p>In addition to looking at the plans and benefits of smart cities, participants examined critical technology needs associated with smart cities, and the financial gaps apparent for realising these goals in relation to energy, the economy, environment, and governance parameters. Participants also exchanged experiences relating to key adjustments required in policy-planning for managing the transition to smart cities. Five cities presented their roadmaps to become smarter, and five thematic papers discussed the challenges and priorities associated with smart city priorities and public-private partnership models.</p><p>On the first day, around 20 participants from India, Japan, and ASEAN countries discussed these issues amongst themselves at the second workshop for the ERIA study on Realising Smart Cities. On the second day, discussions were held at a symposium which included over 100 students, academia, and high-ranking city officials. The symposium provided an opportunity to delve further into questions such as: &lsquo;will information and communication technologies (ICT) allow cities to provide eco-efficiency?&rsquo; and, &lsquo;how does policy convergence helps smart cities evolve?&rsquo; On the third day, the visitors to Salem visited the city hall where they got to hear and see how ICT was being used to improve life in the city and for its citizens.</p><p>Prof. Ponmalai Kolandaivel, Vice-Chancellor of Periyar University, noted during his inaugural address that making cities smarter is not just about what government do, it is about creating a space where different players can bring innovation to bear on public and environmental issues.</p><p>In his welcoming address, Dr Venkatachalam Anbumozhi, ERIA Senior Economist pointed out how smart technologies can give cities a set of powerful and cost-effective tools to enhance service delivery. Furthermore, if they successfully set standards, share best practices and develop actions plans, this could become a significant step forward in transitioning to a low-carbon economy. In the concluding remarks Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA Director of Capacity Building, emphasised the need for broad based strategies for international cooperation amongst the cities, taking advantage of past historical linkages.</p><p>The next meeting for this&nbsp;<em>Smart Cities</em>&nbsp;study is planned to be held in Luang Prabang, Lao PDR, in June 2020, and it will focus on the key policy gaps identified in the smart city survey each participating city is completing.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:145:"/uploads/articles/20200229/2020-april-eria-academics-city-officials-private-sector-international-organisations-discuss-smart-cities-1-800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:38:"smart cities,Innovation and Technology";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6593:"Academics, City Officials, Private Sector, and International Organisations Discuss Issues Related to Smart Cities Academics, City Officials, Private Sector, and International Organisations Discuss Issues Related to Smart Cities Salem, 29 February 2020: What are the current plans and performance indicators for a smart city &ndash; and what are the perceived benefits of a smart city? These are some of the issues that a diverse range of academics, city officials, the private sector, and representatives of international organisations, grappled with at a workshop and symposium titled &lsquo;Driving Sustainability Innovations Through Smart Cities&rsquo; held at Periyar University, Salem, India, from 27 to 29 February.
In addition to looking at the plans and benefits of smart cities, participants examined critical technology needs associated with smart cities, and the financial gaps apparent for realising these goals in relation to energy, the economy, environment, and governance parameters. Participants also exchanged experiences relating to key adjustments required in policy-planning for managing the transition to smart cities. Five cities presented their roadmaps to become smarter, and five thematic papers discussed the challenges and priorities associated with smart city priorities and public-private partnership models.
On the first day, around 20 participants from India, Japan, and ASEAN countries discussed these issues amongst themselves at the second workshop for the ERIA study on Realising Smart Cities. On the second day, discussions were held at a symposium which included over 100 students, academia, and high-ranking city officials. The symposium provided an opportunity to delve further into questions such as: &lsquo;will information and communication technologies (ICT) allow cities to provide eco-efficiency?&rsquo; and, &lsquo;how does policy convergence helps smart cities evolve?&rsquo; On the third day, the visitors to Salem visited the city hall where they got to hear and see how ICT was being used to improve life in the city and for its citizens.
Prof. Ponmalai Kolandaivel, Vice-Chancellor of Periyar University, noted during his inaugural address that making cities smarter is not just about what government do, it is about creating a space where different players can bring innovation to bear on public and environmental issues.
In his welcoming address, Dr Venkatachalam Anbumozhi, ERIA Senior Economist pointed out how smart technologies can give cities a set of powerful and cost-effective tools to enhance service delivery. Furthermore, if they successfully set standards, share best practices and develop actions plans, this could become a significant step forward in transitioning to a low-carbon economy. In the concluding remarks Mr Jeremy Gross, ERIA Director of Capacity Building, emphasised the need for broad based strategies for international cooperation amongst the cities, taking advantage of past historical linkages.
The next meeting for this&nbsp;Smart Cities&nbsp;study is planned to be held in Luang Prabang, Lao PDR, in June 2020, and it will focus on the key policy gaps identified in the smart city survey each participating city is completing. smart cities,Innovation and Technology            2020-02-29 29 February 2020 0202 yraurbeF 92 92-20-0202            ygolonhceT dna noitavonnI,seitic trams .gnitelpmoc si ytic gnitapicitrap hcae yevrus ytic trams eht ni deifitnedi spag ycilop yek eht no sucof lliw ti dna ,0202 enuJ ni ,RDP oaL ,gnabarP gnauL ni dleh eb ot dennalp si yduts;psbn&seitiC tramS;psbn&siht rof gniteem txen ehT

This symposium was tied to the economic policy modelling workshop series for Cambodian government officials, organized by ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme with support from the Australian Government.</p><p>Opening comments were delivered by H.E. Ros Seilava, Under-Secretary of State, Ministry of Economy and Finance, and Mr David Bloch, First Secretary, Australian Embassy, Cambodia. These were followed by a Key Note Speech delivered by Dr Jayant Menon, then Lead Economist at the Asian Development Bank.</p><p>Participants in the workshop series presented their research papers, which they had developed over the previous months, at the symposium. The research papers were entitled:&nbsp;</p><ul><li>Opportunities and Challenges of Investment in Cambodia: Importance of Investment Promotion and Facilitation</li><li>Digital Economy: Emerging Challenges for Cambodia</li><li>Trade, Fiscal Status, and Economic Liberalisation</li><li>Reducing Domestic Vulnerability of Domestic Economy to External Shocks: Case of Cambodia</li><li>Regionalism and Structural Adjustments Using FTAs</li><li>Social Assistance Programs Contribution to Human Capital Development: School Food Feeding Program in Cambodia</li></ul><p>Prizes were awarded to the top three papers, with the 1st prize being presented to the team from the Ministry of Economy and Finance for their paper on &#039;Digital Economy: Emerging Challenges for Cambodia&#039;.</p><p>The workshop series followed the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding between Dr Aun Pornmoniroth, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Economy and Finance, and ERIA. Nearly 40 participants from the Ministry of Economy and Finance, the Ministry of Commerce and the National Bank of Cambodia participated in the two workshops and symposium.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:103:"/uploads/articles/20191104/2019-november-eria-capacity-building-policy-modelling-workshop-1-564x318.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:33:"Economic Policy Modeling,Workshop";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4221:"Prizes for Best Research Paper in Capacity Building Policy Modelling Workshop Series Prizes for Best Research Paper in Capacity Building Policy Modelling Workshop Series Phnom Penh, 4 November 2019: A symposium was held on a &lsquo;Inclusive and sustainable Development in an Open Economy&rsquo; on 4 November 2019 in Phnom Penh. This symposium was tied to the economic policy modelling workshop series for Cambodian government officials, organized by ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme with support from the Australian Government.
Opening comments were delivered by H.E. Ros Seilava, Under-Secretary of State, Ministry of Economy and Finance, and Mr David Bloch, First Secretary, Australian Embassy, Cambodia. These were followed by a Key Note Speech delivered by Dr Jayant Menon, then Lead Economist at the Asian Development Bank.
Participants in the workshop series presented their research papers, which they had developed over the previous months, at the symposium. The research papers were entitled:&nbsp;

Opportunities and Challenges of Investment in Cambodia: Importance of Investment Promotion and Facilitation
Digital Economy: Emerging Challenges for Cambodia
Trade, Fiscal Status, and Economic Liberalisation
Reducing Domestic Vulnerability of Domestic Economy to External Shocks: Case of Cambodia
Regionalism and Structural Adjustments Using FTAs
Social Assistance Programs Contribution to Human Capital Development: School Food Feeding Program in Cambodia

Prizes were awarded to the top three papers, with the 1st prize being presented to the team from the Ministry of Economy and Finance for their paper on 'Digital Economy: Emerging Challenges for Cambodia'.
The workshop series followed the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding between Dr Aun Pornmoniroth, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Economy and Finance, and ERIA. Nearly 40 participants from the Ministry of Economy and Finance, the Ministry of Commerce and the National Bank of Cambodia participated in the two workshops and symposium. The workshops were designed to help officials from each of the identified ASEAN Member States (AMS) to assess for themselves the value of the negative list approach. The workshops were held in Ha Noi in March 2019, Vientiane in October 2019, Phnom Penh in November 2019 and Nay Pyi Taw in January 2020.</p><p>These workshops resulted from the meetings held between the Coordinating Committee on Services (CCS) of AMS and Japan in March and May 2019, at which offers to provide capacity building around preparing the negative list were made. The trainers for the Viet Nam, Cambodia and Lao PDR workshop were Ms Emi Nagaoka, Attorney-at-Law, Baba &amp; Sawada, Ms Avryl Lattin, Partner at Clyde &amp; Co, Sydney, and Dr Intan M. Ramli (ERIA). The Myanmar workshop was facilitated by Mr Richard Braddock, Partner at Lexbridge Lawyers, Canberra, and Mr Ishido Shimpei, Attorney-at-Law at Nishimura and Asahi, and Dr Intan M. Ramli (ERIA).</p><p>The workshops covered issues including trade in services negotiating approaches, introduction to the negative list approach, practice on reading and writing negative lists and transposing from positive lists to negative lists. These workshops were primarily funded by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), Japan. Partnering with ERIA through ERIA&rsquo;s Australian Government funded Capacity Building Programme, widened the perspectives shared with participants by bringing in Australian co-facilitators. Assessment was also done in terms of ascertaining the value of conducting these capacity building programme for the identified AMS.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:82:"/uploads/articles/20200406/2020-january-eria-capacity-building-atisa-2-800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:23:"Capacity Building,Trade";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3961:"Capacity Building on ASEAN Trade in Services Agreement: the Negative List Approach Capacity Building on ASEAN Trade in Services Agreement: the Negative List Approach Between March 2019 and January 2020, four workshops were held to improve understanding of the negative list approach under the ASEAN Trade in Services Agreement (ATISA). The workshops were designed to help officials from each of the identified ASEAN Member States (AMS) to assess for themselves the value of the negative list approach. The workshops were held in Ha Noi in March 2019, Vientiane in October 2019, Phnom Penh in November 2019 and Nay Pyi Taw in January 2020.
These workshops resulted from the meetings held between the Coordinating Committee on Services (CCS) of AMS and Japan in March and May 2019, at which offers to provide capacity building around preparing the negative list were made. The trainers for the Viet Nam, Cambodia and Lao PDR workshop were Ms Emi Nagaoka, Attorney-at-Law, Baba &amp; Sawada, Ms Avryl Lattin, Partner at Clyde &amp; Co, Sydney, and Dr Intan M. Ramli (ERIA). The Myanmar workshop was facilitated by Mr Richard Braddock, Partner at Lexbridge Lawyers, Canberra, and Mr Ishido Shimpei, Attorney-at-Law at Nishimura and Asahi, and Dr Intan M. Ramli (ERIA).
The workshops covered issues including trade in services negotiating approaches, introduction to the negative list approach, practice on reading and writing negative lists and transposing from positive lists to negative lists. These workshops were primarily funded by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), Japan. Partnering with ERIA through ERIA&rsquo;s Australian Government funded Capacity Building Programme, widened the perspectives shared with participants by bringing in Australian co-facilitators. Assessment was also done in terms of ascertaining the value of conducting these capacity building programme for the identified AMS. Aging Prize for Asian Innovation";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2019-12-23";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2019";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"12";s:7:"content";s:2388:"<p>The people of Asia are living longer than ever, presenting a vast array of new challenges and new opportunities that all sectors of society are just beginning to explore and address.</p><p>To recognize and amplify innovative work that seeks to address these challenges, ERIA in partnership with the Japan Center for International Exchange (JCIE) is pleased to announce the <a title="Healthy Aging Prize for Asian Innovation" href="https://www.ahwin.org/award" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Healthy Aging Prize for Asian Innovation</a>.</p><p>The Prize will be awarded to policies, programmes, services, and products in the following categories, with Grand Prize Winners receiving recognition at an international forum to be held in 2020:</p><h3>Technology &amp; Innovation</h3><p>New technologies and techniques that encourage healthy and productive aging, that improve the way that older persons receive care, or that provide greater efficiency, safety, and/or convenience for older persons and caregivers.</p><h3>Community-based Initiatives</h3><p>Community-based approaches&mdash;including inter-generational approaches&mdash;to keeping older adults healthy, active, engaged, and/or safe.</p><h3>Supporting Self-Reliance</h3><p>New ways to help older adults maintain, improve, or restore physical and mental functions, that assist them and their caregivers as those functions deteriorate, or that build resilience.</p><p>To learn more about the Prize and how to apply please visit <a title="Asia Health and Wellbeing Initiative" href="https://www.ahwin.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">the AHWIN website</a>.</p><p>Please feel free to forward this information to other people in your network who are running innovative programs in aging and might be interested in the Award.</p><h2>Related Documents</h2><p class="pdf"><a title="Healthy Aging Prize for Asian Innovation" href="/uploads/media/2019-December-Healthy-Aging-Prize-for-Asian-Innovation.pdf" Innovation</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:55:"/uploads/articles/20191223/istock-458104451-800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:17:"healthcare,ageing";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3517:"Healthy Aging Prize for Asian Innovation Healthy Aging Prize for Asian Innovation The people of Asia are living longer than ever, presenting a vast array of new challenges and new opportunities that all sectors of society are just beginning to explore and address.
To recognize and amplify innovative work that seeks to address these challenges, ERIA in partnership with the Japan Center for International Exchange (JCIE) is pleased to announce the Healthy Aging Prize for Asian Innovation.
The Prize will be awarded to policies, programmes, services, and products in the following categories, with Grand Prize Winners receiving recognition at an international forum to be held in 2020:
Technology &amp; Innovation
New technologies and techniques that encourage healthy and productive aging, that improve the way that older persons receive care, or that provide greater efficiency, safety, and/or convenience for older persons and caregivers.
Community-based Initiatives
Community-based approaches&mdash;including inter-generational approaches&mdash;to keeping older adults healthy, active, engaged, and/or safe.
Supporting Self-Reliance
New ways to help older adults maintain, improve, or restore physical and mental functions, that assist them and their caregivers as those functions deteriorate, or that build resilience.
To learn more about the Prize and how to apply please visit the AHWIN website.
Please feel free to forward this information to other people in your network who are running innovative programs in aging and might be interested in the Award.

The quickly increasing elderly population will create greater demand for long-term care. This report provides care demand estimates for the coming decades based on the care need statistics of several countries, as well as the increasing numbers of elderly people living alone, which significantly affects care demand. As for the supply of long-term care, this publication reports on the current status of the care workforce, which varies from country to country depending on the stage of development of the long-term care system. The situation of long-term care facilities is also briefly analysed.</p><p>Data comparison amongst countries highlights the existing challenges. Rapid increases in care need should be addressed through a system providing long-term care and policy dialogues should be encouraged.</p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Download Demand and Supply of Long-term Care for Older Persons in Asia" href="/research/demand-and-supply-of-long-term-care-for-older-persons-in-asia/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Download Demand and Supply of Long-term Care for Older Persons in Asia</a></p><h2 class="detail">Functional Recovery Care</h2><p>ERIA, in cooperation with the Japan Society of Functional Recovery Care and Power Rehabilitation, created the teaching materials of &lsquo;Functional Recovery Care&rsquo;. This textbook and its accompanying video series is one of the ways to educate care workers as a step towards the achievement of healthy and active ageing in Asia.&nbsp;</p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Download Functional Recovery Care Textbook" href="/research/functional-recovery-care/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Download Functional Recovery Care Textbook</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Playlist for the Basic Theory of Japanese &#039;Functional Recovery Care&#039;" href="http://bit.ly/2IEXmfD" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Playlist for the Basic Theory of Japanese &#039;Functional Recovery Care&#039;</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Playlist for the Practical Method of Japanese &#039;Functional Recovery Care&#039;" href="http://bit.ly/2IzGLcV" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Playlist for the Practical Method of Japanese &#039;Functional Recovery Care&#039;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:55:"/uploads/articles/20191024/istock-875613956_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:65:"Healthcare,ageing society,ageing in Asia,functional recovery care";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3547:"Healthcare and Ageing Society Publications Healthcare and Ageing Society Publications Demand and Supply of Long-term Care for Older Persons in Asia
In East and Southeast Asia, the numbers and proportions of older persons are increasing. The quickly increasing elderly population will create greater demand for long-term care. This report provides care demand estimates for the coming decades based on the care need statistics of several countries, as well as the increasing numbers of elderly people living alone, which significantly affects care demand. As for the supply of long-term care, this publication reports on the current status of the care workforce, which varies from country to country depending on the stage of development of the long-term care system. The situation of long-term care facilities is also briefly analysed.
Data comparison amongst countries highlights the existing challenges. Rapid increases in care need should be addressed through a system providing long-term care and policy dialogues should be encouraged.
Download Demand and Supply of Long-term Care for Older Persons in Asia
Functional Recovery Care
ERIA, in cooperation with the Japan Society of Functional Recovery Care and Power Rehabilitation, created the teaching materials of &lsquo;Functional Recovery Care&rsquo;. This textbook and its accompanying video series is one of the ways to educate care workers as a step towards the achievement of healthy and active ageing in Asia.&nbsp;

the Readiness of ASEAN Smart Cities Enhancing the Readiness of ASEAN Smart Cities Chiang Mai, 24 July 2019&nbsp;- ERIA, in collaboration with Asian Institute of Technology (AIT), Srinidhorn International Institute of Technology (SIIT), and Chiang Mai Municipality, organised a two-day workshop on &lsquo;Realising Smart Cities&rsquo; on 23 and 24 July in Chiang Mai, Thailand. The workshop examined how cities can develop smart city programmes including the costs versus benefits.
Experts analysed critical needs including energy, economy, environment, and governance while exchanging experiences on key adjustments required in policy planning relating to the transition to smart cities. They also addressed sustainability implications identified necessary measurements and data protocols required to enhance the readiness of ASEAN smart cities. &nbsp;
About 30 experts representing academia, city officials and private sector participated.
Highlights

Urbanisation fuelling economic growth, but its pace leaving many cities struggling to meet multi-dimensional economic, environmental, and social challenges and providing services to meet the needs of surging services by both the young and ageing population. While the challenges have been growing in scope, new technologies are available to tackle some of these issues, particularly in energy and environment.
Smart cities paving the way for new methods of city governance by harnessing the potentials of the Internet of Things (IoT) through the utilisation of information and communication technologies throughout the city. By deploying responsive technologies across urban systems such as energy, water, public transport, street lighting, parking, and waste management, the smart city initiative aims to increase the quality of life and service delivery.
Data feeds collected from all over the city need to be brought together into central computing platforms, processed, and analysed. Outputs can be distributed to the users and decision makers.
Without a strategic vision for economic integration, infusion of IoT into various versions of smart city may yield differentiated outcomes and delayed implementation. The Comprehensive Asia Development Plan (CADP 3.0) offers a wholistic thinking for more successful urbanisation and economy for the future cities.
The challenges and risks arising from smart city projects also need elaboration through further research. Moreover, providing methodologies to cope with important IoT-centric smart city challenges such as the privacy rights of data users/residents, is still an area where further research is needed.

The workshop was held with support from the Australian Government.</p><p>The workshop was opened with a key note given by U Sai Saw Lin Tun, Director General of Information Technology and Cyber Security, MoTC, Martine Kidane, Economic Affairs Officer, ICT Policy of UNCTAD and Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building of ERIA.</p><p>The first day of the workshop was attended by over 80 government officials from all ministries and agencies involved in e-commerce. The first session covered, <em>Tr</em><em>end</em><em>s and Developments in Digitalization and E-Commerce: Globally and Regionally</em>, with speakers Ms Martine Julsaint Kidane and Ms Maria Lourdes A. Yaptinchay, Director, Bureau of Trade and Industrial Policy Research, Dept of Trade and Industry, the Philippines.</p><p>The second session was on<em> Developments in Digitalization and National Development Strategies for E-Commerce in Myanmar</em> and <em>Bridging National Interests and Global Trends </em>with Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade and E-Trade Adviser, Daw Nwe Ni Soe Yin, Director, Information Technology and Cyber Security Department, MoTC, Daw Su Thet Hnin, Assistant Director, Trade Department, Ministry of Commerce and Dr Tun Thura Thet, Vice President, Myanmar Computer Federation and CEO, Myanmar Information Technology PTE, as speakers.</p><p>The third session was an opportunity to hear more specifically from the private sector, with speakers coming from leading e-commerce players in Myanmar: Visa, Shop.com.mm, SBS Express Service, Information Matrix Co., Ltd. Representatives from these companies shared knowledge of global and regional trends and development in digitalization, how Myanmar is faring with the development of digitalization and E- commerce and how the gap between the country&rsquo;s current situation and global trends of e-commerce could be bridged.</p><p>The second day of the workshop was limited to 30 participants &ndash; those more directly involved in negotiating. The experts presented on how government should prepare for negotiation, how to enhance International Trade and Regional Integration thorough E-commerce and gave an overview of E-commerce provisions in Free Trade Area (FTA) negotiations. There were group discussions and simulation exercise on different topics related with E-commerce negotiation.</p><p>After these presentations and discussions, participants were divided into small groups for a simulation exercise on selected issues such as cross boarder data flow, custom duties and online consumer protections.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:79:"/uploads/articles/20190722/2019_july_eria-cbp-e-commerce-workshop_4_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:36:"Capacity Building,Workshop,ecommerce";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:7:"Myanmar";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:5827:"ERIA CBP Holds Workshop on E-commerce in Naypyitaw ERIA CBP Holds Workshop on E-commerce in Naypyitaw On 11-12 July 2019, ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme facilitated a workshop in Nay Pyi Taw on 'E-commerce for Trade Negotiators', co-hosted with the Ministry of Transport and Communications (MoTC), Republic of the Union of Myanmar and UNCTAD. The workshop was held with support from the Australian Government.
The workshop was opened with a key note given by U Sai Saw Lin Tun, Director General of Information Technology and Cyber Security, MoTC, Martine Kidane, Economic Affairs Officer, ICT Policy of UNCTAD and Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building of ERIA.
The first day of the workshop was attended by over 80 government officials from all ministries and agencies involved in e-commerce. The first session covered, Trends and Developments in Digitalization and E-Commerce: Globally and Regionally, with speakers Ms Martine Julsaint Kidane and Ms Maria Lourdes A. Yaptinchay, Director, Bureau of Trade and Industrial Policy Research, Dept of Trade and Industry, the Philippines.
The second session was on Developments in Digitalization and National Development Strategies for E-Commerce in Myanmar and Bridging National Interests and Global Trends with Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade and E-Trade Adviser, Daw Nwe Ni Soe Yin, Director, Information Technology and Cyber Security Department, MoTC, Daw Su Thet Hnin, Assistant Director, Trade Department, Ministry of Commerce and Dr Tun Thura Thet, Vice President, Myanmar Computer Federation and CEO, Myanmar Information Technology PTE, as speakers.
The third session was an opportunity to hear more specifically from the private sector, with speakers coming from leading e-commerce players in Myanmar: Visa, Shop.com.mm, SBS Express Service, Information Matrix Co., Ltd. Representatives from these companies shared knowledge of global and regional trends and development in digitalization, how Myanmar is faring with the development of digitalization and E- commerce and how the gap between the country&rsquo;s current situation and global trends of e-commerce could be bridged.
The second day of the workshop was limited to 30 participants &ndash; those more directly involved in negotiating. The experts presented on how government should prepare for negotiation, how to enhance International Trade and Regional Integration thorough E-commerce and gave an overview of E-commerce provisions in Free Trade Area (FTA) negotiations. There were group discussions and simulation exercise on different topics related with E-commerce negotiation.
After these presentations and discussions, participants were divided into small groups for a simulation exercise on selected issues such as cross boarder data flow, custom duties and online consumer protections. connectivity and globalisation and its links to sustainable development, with a particular focus on the Asia-Europe context.</p><p>Conference topics include (but are not limited Technologies</li></ul><p>Research should address international connectivity (as opposed to domestic), and particular preference will be given to research targeting Asia-Europe connectivity.&nbsp; Datasets are available in the&nbsp;<a href="https://composite-indicators.jrc.ec.europa.eu/asem-sustainable-connectivity/repository" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Repository</a>&nbsp;section.</p><h2>Submission process</h2><p>Interested researchers should submit a short text abstract which summarises their research and any key findings, using the form below. All abstracts will be peer-reviewed by the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.aescon.org/committees/">Scientific Committee</a>&nbsp;of AESCON. For accepted abstracts, participants will also be required to submit an extended 2-3 page abstract, including key figures and tables, which will feature in the conference proceedings and will be publically available from the conference website.</p><p>The abstract submission process is as follows:</p><ul><li>1 July 2019: Call for abstracts is open</li><li>6 October 2019: Extended deadline for abstracts</li><li>31 October 2019: Researchers are notified of acceptance or rejection of abstracts, and will be required to confirm their attendance to the conference</li><li>1 November 2019: Conference registration opens</li><li>31 December 2019: Deadline for submission of extended abstract</li></ul><h2><a class="bluebtn" title="Call for Abstracts | AESCON" href="https://www.aescon.org/call-for-abstracts/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Submit your abstract here</a></h2><h2>Special Issue</h2><p>AESCON aims to offer researchers the opportunity to publish high-quality papers in a special issue on Sustainable Connectivity of a leading journal on issues relating to globalisation. The submission process to the special issue will open after the conference. More details on this will appear shortly.</p><h2>Costs</h2><p>Registration to AESCON is free of charge, but participants will need to cover the costs of their travel and accommodation. The acceptance to the conference is subject to the approval of the organisers, so please do not book your travel before having received a confirmation letter.</p><p>In order to encourage participation from a wide range of countries, and to promote a balanced group of participants, AESCON may be able to fund the travel of a very limited number of participants in particular justified cases where their institution is unable to provide funds. In such cases, travel funding would be available subject to the approval of the organising committee and with strong justification from the participant.</p><h2>Submission</h2><p><a title="Call for Abstracts" href="https://www.aescon.org/call-for-abstracts/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Click here</a> to submit your abstract.</p><p>Source:&nbsp;<a title="Call for Abstracts" href="https://www.aescon.org/call-for-abstracts/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Call for Abstracts</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:57:"/uploads/articles/20190703/1240x858_call-for-abstracs.gif";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6241:"AESCON Call for Abstracts AESCON Call for Abstracts AESCON welcomes original research on international connectivity and globalisation and its links to sustainable development, with a particular focus on the Asia-Europe context.
Conference topics include (but are not limited to):

Transport
Energy
Digital economy and e-commerce
Political and institutional cooperation
Education and research
Migration
Tourism
Interoperability
Trade
Financial networks and flows
Cultural exchanges
Security
Information and Communication Technologies

Research should address international connectivity (as opposed to domestic), and particular preference will be given to research targeting Asia-Europe connectivity.&nbsp; Research should also adopt an integrated approach to connectivity, by linking the chosen connectivity topic to sustainability considerations and assessments.&nbsp; Participants are highly encouraged to use data from the&nbsp;ASEM Sustainable Connectivity Portal. Datasets are available in the&nbsp;Repository&nbsp;section.
Submission process
Interested researchers should submit a short text abstract which summarises their research and any key findings, using the form below. All abstracts will be peer-reviewed by the&nbsp;Scientific Committee&nbsp;of AESCON. For accepted abstracts, participants will also be required to submit an extended 2-3 page abstract, including key figures and tables, which will feature in the conference proceedings and will be publically available from the conference website.
The abstract submission process is as follows:

1 July 2019: Call for abstracts is open
6 October 2019: Extended deadline for abstracts
31 October 2019: Researchers are notified of acceptance or rejection of abstracts, and will be required to confirm their attendance to the conference
1 November 2019: Conference registration opens
31 December 2019: Deadline for submission of extended abstract

Submit your abstract here
Special Issue
AESCON aims to offer researchers the opportunity to publish high-quality papers in a special issue on Sustainable Connectivity of a leading journal on issues relating to globalisation. The submission process to the special issue will open after the conference. More details on this will appear shortly.
Costs
Registration to AESCON is free of charge, but participants will need to cover the costs of their travel and accommodation. The acceptance to the conference is subject to the approval of the organisers, so please do not book your travel before having received a confirmation letter.
In order to encourage participation from a wide range of countries, and to promote a balanced group of participants, AESCON may be able to fund the travel of a very limited number of participants in particular justified cases where their institution is unable to provide funds. In such cases, travel funding would be available subject to the approval of the organising committee and with strong justification from the participant.
Submission
Click here to submit your abstract.

Asia";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3791:"Teaching Materials for Functional Recovery Care Teaching Materials for Functional Recovery Care The Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), in cooperation with the Japan Society of Functional Recovery Care and Power Rehabilitation, created the teaching materials of &lsquo;Functional Recovery Care&rsquo;. This textbook and its accompanying video series is one of the ways to educate care workers as a step towards the achievement of healthy and active ageing in Asia.&nbsp;Asia is facing a massive demographic shift. By 2050, the number of people in Asia who are aged 65 or older is expected to grow to 937 million people&mdash;more than double of today's number.&nbsp;Recognising the inevitable impact this will have on the region, the Japanese government launched the Asia Health and Wellbeing Initiative (AHWIN) in 2016 to share information and resources on ageing with Asian countries.&nbsp;Japan is the fastest ageing society in the world that has grappled with the problems deriving from ageing for many years; thus, it has accumulated valuable experience and lessons. For example, The Functional Recovery Care is one of the approaches that help seniors regain their ability to live independently.
 
 Functional Recovery Care  from Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia

Functional Recovery Care Text
View Videos
There are two series of short videos, the first one on the theory and the other one is on the practical methods to assist seniors in regaining their ability to live independently.
The videos are available on ERIA's Youtube Channel&nbsp;&nbsp;or start watching the first video below.

15:02:19";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";N;s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:219;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"5064";s:12:"article_type";s:8:"articles";s:3:"uri";s:73:"eria-hosts-workshop-on-long-term-care-for-elderly-caregivers-in-indonesia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:73:"ERIA Hosts Workshop on Long-term Care for Elderly Caregivers in Indonesia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2019-03-22";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2019";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"3";s:7:"content";s:3051:"<p>The Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) in cooperation with Universitas Respati Indonesia (URINDO) held an &lsquo;International Workshop for Research Dissemination: Need Assessment for Long-term Care including Oral Care for Indonesian Elderly Caregiver&rsquo; on 20 March 2019 in ERIA&rsquo;s Jakarta Office.</p><p>The workshop was part of an ongoing research project spearheaded by an Indonesian and Japanese team. The project focuses on long-term care in the Indonesian provinces of Jakarta, Banten, West Java, and Yogyakarta. After successfully completing the project, the research team is seeking to expand the research to other Asian countries by utilising the model which would be developed through Indonesian site.</p><p>The project is specifically designed for caregivers with the hope of contributing to Indonesia&rsquo;s healthcare workers as well as creating a standardised care for caregivers of the elderly. The collaboration between the Indonesian and Japanese teams were partly due to the significant presence of Indonesian caregivers within Japan&rsquo;s long-term elderly care. Prof Yuko Hirano, a Professor in the Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences at Nagasaki University, stated that there are approximately 1,494 Indonesian caregivers who are based in Japan.</p><p>Moreover, Prof Hirano stated that there are approximately 1,792 Indonesian caregivers that have been dispatched from Indonesia through Japan-Indonesia Economic Partnership Agreement since 2008.&nbsp; Prof Hirano mentioned that more and more Indonesian caregivers would enter Japan through another track, such as Technical Internship Training Program, Specified Skilled Worker, and students who enrolled to caregiver course in Japan.</p><p>Meanwhile, there has also been a growing pressure in Indonesia to focus on the elderly citizens, which is expected to make up 13.2% of the country&rsquo;s population by 2025, according to the Rector of URINDO Prof Tri Budi W. Rahardjo.&nbsp;</p><p>During the event, the speakers emphasised on a number of key issues, including paying&nbsp;more attention&nbsp;to oral care of elderly people due to increased health risks if&nbsp;it&nbsp;is neglected. Oral care is important because it requires more invasive care; therefore, the caregivers need appropriate knowledge and skills on oral care for the elderly. At the event, participants were introduced to the &lsquo;Higashijima Oral Care List&rsquo;. The module has continuously been developed since its creation to ensure that it can become a universal module of oral care for the elderly.</p><p>The event included a lively discussion regarding the challenges facing Indonesia&rsquo;s elderly population from participants who are directly involved in assisting elderly people. The participants comprised of professionals from private and public healthcare institutions. After the conclusion of the event, the Indonesian and Japanese teams will forge onwards in completing the research project, taking into account the input from event participa</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:76:"/uploads/articles/20190322/2019_mar_eria-workshop-elderly-care_1_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:38:"healthcare,ageing,Indonesia,caregivers";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:7:"Jakarta";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6489:"ERIA Hosts Workshop on Long-term Care for Elderly Caregivers in Indonesia ERIA Hosts Workshop on Long-term Care for Elderly Caregivers in Indonesia The Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) in cooperation with Universitas Respati Indonesia (URINDO) held an &lsquo;International Workshop for Research Dissemination: Need Assessment for Long-term Care including Oral Care for Indonesian Elderly Caregiver&rsquo; on 20 March 2019 in ERIA&rsquo;s Jakarta Office.
The workshop was part of an ongoing research project spearheaded by an Indonesian and Japanese team. The project focuses on long-term care in the Indonesian provinces of Jakarta, Banten, West Java, and Yogyakarta. After successfully completing the project, the research team is seeking to expand the research to other Asian countries by utilising the model which would be developed through Indonesian site.
The project is specifically designed for caregivers with the hope of contributing to Indonesia&rsquo;s healthcare workers as well as creating a standardised care for caregivers of the elderly. The collaboration between the Indonesian and Japanese teams were partly due to the significant presence of Indonesian caregivers within Japan&rsquo;s long-term elderly care. Prof Yuko Hirano, a Professor in the Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences at Nagasaki University, stated that there are approximately 1,494 Indonesian caregivers who are based in Japan.
Moreover, Prof Hirano stated that there are approximately 1,792 Indonesian caregivers that have been dispatched from Indonesia through Japan-Indonesia Economic Partnership Agreement since 2008.&nbsp; Prof Hirano mentioned that more and more Indonesian caregivers would enter Japan through another track, such as Technical Internship Training Program, Specified Skilled Worker, and students who enrolled to caregiver course in Japan.
Meanwhile, there has also been a growing pressure in Indonesia to focus on the elderly citizens, which is expected to make up 13.2% of the country&rsquo;s population by 2025, according to the Rector of URINDO Prof Tri Budi W. Rahardjo.&nbsp;
During the event, the speakers emphasised on a number of key issues, including paying&nbsp;more attention&nbsp;to oral care of elderly people due to increased health risks if&nbsp;it&nbsp;is neglected. Oral care is important because it requires more invasive care; therefore, the caregivers need appropriate knowledge and skills on oral care for the elderly. At the event, participants were introduced to the &lsquo;Higashijima Oral Care List&rsquo;. The module has continuously been developed since its creation to ensure that it can become a universal module of oral care for the elderly.
The event included a lively discussion regarding the challenges facing Indonesia&rsquo;s elderly population from participants who are directly involved in assisting elderly people. The participants comprised of professionals from private and public healthcare institutions. After the conclusion of the event, the Indonesian and Japanese teams will forge onwards in completing the research project, taking into account the input from event participa healthcare,ageing,Indonesia,caregivers      Jakarta      2019-03-22 22 March 2019 9102 hcraM 22 22-30-9102      atrakaJ      srevigerac,aisenodnI,gniega,erachtlaeh apicitrap tneve morf tupni eht tnuocca otni gnikat ,tcejorp hcraeser eht gnitelpmoc ni sdrawno egrof lliw smaet esenapaJ dna naisenodnI eht ,tneve eht fo noisulcnoc eht retfA .snoitutitsni erachtlaeh cilbup dna etavirp morf slanoisseforp fo desirpmoc stnapicitrap ehT .elpoep ylredle gnitsissa ni devlovni yltcerid era ohw stnapicitrap morf noitalupop ylredle s;ouqsr&aisenodnI gnicaf segnellahc eht gnidrager noissucsid ylevil a dedulcni tneve ehT

Initiative</a></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:44:"/uploads/articles/20190122/ahwin_800x450.png";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:2603:"ERIA and JCIE LaunchÂ a New Website for Healthy Ageing in Asia ERIA and JCIE LaunchÂ a New Website for Healthy Ageing in Asia ERIA is excited to announce the launch of a new website we have developed in partnership with Japan Center for International Exchange (JCIE) to disseminate key data and resources on ageing in Asia and share best practices to respond to this demographic shift.
Under the auspices of the Cabinet Secretariat of Japan, ERIA has worked with JCIE to launch the AHWIN website, which will serve as a platform for sharing:&nbsp;

interactive and downloadable data on ageing in Asia
policy lessons learned in Japan and other countries where ageing is already advanced
examples of innovative products, services, and programs to deal with ageing-related issues
information on AHWIN-supported research and dialogues


Currently, the policy lessons and innovative approaches highlighted on the site focus on Japan, but in the future, those sections will provide information and resources from throughout Asia.
We hope that this site will become a useful hub for those addressing the issue of ageing.

.tfihs cihpargomed siht ot dnopser ot secitcarp tseb erahs dna aisA ni gniega no secruoser dna atad yek etanimessid ot )EICJ( egnahcxE lanoitanretnI rof retneC napaJ htiw pihsrentrap ni depoleved evah ew etisbew wen a fo hcnual eht ecnuonna ot deticxe si AIRE aisA ni gniegA yhtlaeH rof etisbeW weN a ÂhcnuaL EICJ dna AIRE aisA ni gniegA yhtlaeH rof etisbeW weN a ÂhcnuaL EICJ dna AIRE";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2019-01-22 10:15:25";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2019-01-22 12:40:15";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";N;s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:221;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"4677";s:12:"article_type";s:8:"articles";s:3:"uri";s:97:"government-officials-participate-in-study-on-distributional-effects-of-disaster-and-food-security";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:97:"Government Officials Participate in Study on Distributional Effects of Disaster and Food Security";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2017-07-18";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2017";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:2222:"<div id="news-content"><div id="news-text"><p>In a region prone to natural disasters and where the potential impact of climate change on agriculture is high, governments are starting to pay serious attention to the issue of future food security.</p><p>Responding to these challenges, ERIA has initiated a study,&#039;Distributional Effects of Disasters and Climate Change on Food Security in ASEAN&#039;. The objective is to understand the effects disasters and climate change will have on food security for nations in the region, and identify actions needed to be taken by policy makers to mitigate the risks by adjusting key planning instruments and developing other adaptive measures. ERIA&#039;s study is being led by ERIA Senior Economist, Dr Venkatachalam Anbumohzhi.</p><p>At the technical workshop for this study held in Putrajaya, Malaysia, on 17 July, 11 papers were presented on various topics held around three themes:</p><ul><li>Estimation of the overall damage and losses on food production and distribution due to disasters and climate change</li><li>Identification and assessment of strategies for resilience and food security</li><li>Necessary conditions for developing adaptable road maps</li></ul><p>The technical papers for the study are being written by academics and senior officials from international organisations in the region. As it is critical to ensure government officials are fully aware and engaged in discussions on these issue, through ERIA&#039;s Capacity Building Programme, officials from Cambodia, India, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Malaysia, Myanmar and Viet Nam also participated. In addition to acting as discussants for each paper presented, their contributions to the discussions allowed for a rich mix of academic, practical and policy oriented approaches to the study.</p></div><div><p>Also participating in the event were representatives from the UN Centre for Alleviation of Poverty through Sustainable Agriculture (CAPSA) and the Malaysian Agricultural Research and Development Institute (MARDI). The ERIA workshop is being held back to back with one organised by MARDI and CAPSA on agricultural resilience to support peer learning.</p></div></div><div id="image-table">&nbsp;</div>";s:10:"image_name";s:73:"/uploads/articles/20180416/2017_july_eria_workshop-puterajaya_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:32:"disasters,Food Security,Workshop";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:19:"Putrajaya, Malaysia";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4697:"Government Officials Participate in Study on Distributional Effects of Disaster and Food Security Government Officials Participate in Study on Distributional Effects of Disaster and Food Security In a region prone to natural disasters and where the potential impact of climate change on agriculture is high, governments are starting to pay serious attention to the issue of future food security.
Responding to these challenges, ERIA has initiated a study,'Distributional Effects of Disasters and Climate Change on Food Security in ASEAN'. The objective is to understand the effects disasters and climate change will have on food security for nations in the region, and identify actions needed to be taken by policy makers to mitigate the risks by adjusting key planning instruments and developing other adaptive measures. ERIA's study is being led by ERIA Senior Economist, Dr Venkatachalam Anbumohzhi.
At the technical workshop for this study held in Putrajaya, Malaysia, on 17 July, 11 papers were presented on various topics held around three themes:

Estimation of the overall damage and losses on food production and distribution due to disasters and climate change
Identification and assessment of strategies for resilience and food security
Necessary conditions for developing adaptable road maps

The technical papers for the study are being written by academics and senior officials from international organisations in the region. As it is critical to ensure government officials are fully aware and engaged in discussions on these issue, through ERIA's Capacity Building Programme, officials from Cambodia, India, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Malaysia, Myanmar and Viet Nam also participated. In addition to acting as discussants for each paper presented, their contributions to the discussions allowed for a rich mix of academic, practical and policy oriented approaches to the study.


Also participating in the event were representatives from the UN Centre for Alleviation of Poverty through Sustainable Agriculture (CAPSA) and the Malaysian Agricultural Research and Development Institute (MARDI). The ERIA workshop is being held back to back with one organised by MARDI and CAPSA on agricultural resilience to support peer learning.

For the first time, one participant also came as a member of Technical Staff (Economics Department) from one of the parliaments, the National Assembly of Lao PDR.</p><p>The workshop was opened by ERIA Capacity Building Coordinator, Mr Jeremy Gross, with welcoming speeches being given by Mr Andreas Zurbrugg, Charge d&#039;Affaires, Australian Embassy to Lao PDR, and Dr Leeber Leebouapao, Director General of Lao&#039;s National Economic Research Institute (NERI). The trainers/facilitators for the workshop were Mr Windhu Hidranto, PPP Specialist, currently Deputy Team Leader, Policy Team - National Roads Program, IndII, Aurecon (Indonesia), Mr John Cheong-Holdaway, an Asset Management and Infrastructure Policy Adviser, and Dr Fauziah Zen, ERIA Economist.</p><p>The workshop was held under ERIA&#039;s Australian Government funded Capacity Building Programme.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:61:"/uploads/articles/20160711/2016_june_ppp-workshop_800x450.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:30:"Capacity Building,Workshop,PPP";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:18:"Vientiane, Lao PDR";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3335:"Pushing PPPs Forward at a Capacity Building Workshop Pushing PPPs Forward at a Capacity Building Workshop On June 27-28 government representatives from Cambodia, Lao PDR, Myanmar and Viet Nam spent two days learning about different models of Public Private Partnerships (PPPs) with a focus on more complex issues around PPPs including financial viability, economic viability and efficient risk allocation.
This hands-on workshop was held in Vientiane, Lao PDR, as part of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia's (ERIA) Capacity Building Programme.
The participants came from different ministries in their respective countries, reflecting the importance of officials from a wide range of ministries understanding the issue. For the first time, one participant also came as a member of Technical Staff (Economics Department) from one of the parliaments, the National Assembly of Lao PDR.
The workshop was opened by ERIA Capacity Building Coordinator, Mr Jeremy Gross, with welcoming speeches being given by Mr Andreas Zurbrugg, Charge d'Affaires, Australian Embassy to Lao PDR, and Dr Leeber Leebouapao, Director General of Lao's National Economic Research Institute (NERI). The trainers/facilitators for the workshop were Mr Windhu Hidranto, PPP Specialist, currently Deputy Team Leader, Policy Team - National Roads Program, IndII, Aurecon (Indonesia), Mr John Cheong-Holdaway, an Asset Management and Infrastructure Policy Adviser, and Dr Fauziah Zen, ERIA Economist.
The workshop was held under ERIA's Australian Government funded Capacity Building Programme. in Singapore, 25-26 March 2018.</p><p>This research project, led by ERIA Senior Economist, Dr Venkatachalam Anbumozhi, brings together experts from the International Food Research Institute in Washington, DC, the Asian Productivity Organisation, Nanyang Technological University, University of Technology Vienna, Asia Pacific University Japan, and the US Department of Agriculture. Government officials from Cambodia, Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam joined the workshop with the experts under ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme, as part of a peer-to-peer process to draft and develop <em>Guidelines on Adaptation Road Maps</em> for policy makers.</p><p>The papers discussed at the workshop included ones focusing on the challenges, impacts and implications of climate change on food security, the challenges of integrating CCA and DRR into national programmes, the feasibility of establishing a taskforce at ASEAN specifically dedicated to CCA and DRR, and mechanisms to mobilise capital to finance DRR and CC programmes.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:71:"/uploads/articles/20180329/2018_march_eria-cbp-singapore_2_800x450.jpeg";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:75:"capacity building,disaster risk reduction,climate change,disasters,Workshop";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:9:"Singapore";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3211:"ERIA Held Research and Capacity Building Workshop on Impacts of Disasters and Climate Change ERIA Held Research and Capacity Building Workshop on Impacts of Disasters and Climate Change In an attempt to mainstream disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) into development planning of the region, ERIA held the second workshop on &lsquo;Evaluating the Distributional Impacts of Disasters and Climate Change and Development of Adaptation Roadmaps&rsquo; in Singapore, 25-26 March 2018.
This research project, led by ERIA Senior Economist, Dr Venkatachalam Anbumozhi, brings together experts from the International Food Research Institute in Washington, DC, the Asian Productivity Organisation, Nanyang Technological University, University of Technology Vienna, Asia Pacific University Japan, and the US Department of Agriculture. Government officials from Cambodia, Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam joined the workshop with the experts under ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme, as part of a peer-to-peer process to draft and develop Guidelines on Adaptation Road Maps for policy makers.
The papers discussed at the workshop included ones focusing on the challenges, impacts and implications of climate change on food security, the challenges of integrating CCA and DRR into national programmes, the feasibility of establishing a taskforce at ASEAN specifically dedicated to CCA and DRR, and mechanisms to mobilise capital to finance DRR and CC programmes. capacity building,disaster risk reduction,climate change,disasters,Workshop      Singapore      2018-03-29 29 March 2018 8102 hcraM 92 92-30-8102      eropagniS      pohskroW,sretsasid,egnahc etamilc,noitcuder ksir retsasid,gnidliub yticapac .semmargorp CC dna RRD ecnanif ot latipac esilibom ot smsinahcem dna ,RRD dna ACC ot detacided yllacificeps NAESA ta ecrofksat a gnihsilbatse fo ytilibisaef eht ,semmargorp lanoitan otni RRD dna ACC gnitargetni fo segnellahc eht ,ytiruces doof no egnahc etamilc fo snoitacilpmi dna stcapmi ,segnellahc eht no gnisucof seno dedulcni pohskrow eht ta dessucsid srepap ehT

This workshop gave a general oversight into issues including Harmonised System (HS) Codes, preferential certificates of origin, customs valuation and SPS requirements.
The facilitator of the workshop was Mr Jonathan Koh, Managing Director of Singaporean firm Trade Facilitation Pte Ltd, a consultancy firm specialising in trade facilitation, trade policy and research. This workshop was a follow-up to a workshop held in May 2017 at the Ministry of Commerce on Understanding Issues for RCEP Negotiations.
The workshop was opened by H.E. Mr Sok Sopheak, Under Secretary of State, Ministry of Commerce. In his opening comments, H.E. Mr Sok Sopheak noted the challenges of the changing international environment, the rise of protectionism, and how the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) will provide a comprehensive free trade agreement that could positively impact the standard of living of Cambodian and other people in the region for the better. To make the most of this, the Ministry is pleased to benefit from technical assistance such as that provided through this workshop which is of particular help to younger negotiators and experienced negotiators and is looking forward for more cooperation with ERIA in the near future.
Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building at ERIA, noted how such support was in-line with ERIA's overall mission to support the deepening of economic integration in the region, for example through its work on NTMs and the trade facilitation index it is currently developing.
